subject: TOMORROW! 2PM:Jose Carmena, Science of Learning Seminar
bodyText:
The neural basis of neuroprosthetic skill learning


Jose Carmena, University of California, Berkeley



Brain-machine interfaces (BMIs) is a novel technology that holds great potential to aid large numbers of people with sensory, motor and cognitive disabilities. BMIs provide also a framework for examining basic neuroscience questions, especially those related to the understanding of how neural plasticity relates to the acquisition and consolidation of neuroprosthetic skills, i.e. accurate, readily-recalled control of disembodied actuators irrespective of natural physical movement. In this talk I will postulate that achieving skillful, natural control of a multi-degree-of-freedom prosthetic device will entail synergizing two different types of adaptation processes: natural (brain plasticity) and artificial (decoder adaptation), as well as providing realistic sensory feedback from the prosthetic device. I will present recent work from our laboratory showing that 1) neuroplasticity facilitates consolidation of neuroprosthetic motor skill in a way that resembles that of natural motor learning; 2) corticostriatal plasticity is necessary for neuroprosthetic skill learning, and 3) closed-loop decoder adaptation (CLDA) techniques can expedite the learning process by adapting the decoder parameters during closed-loop BMI operation (i.e., while the subject is using the BMI).  We believe that BMI systems capable of exploiting both neuroplasticity and CLDA will be able to boost learning, generalize well to novel movements and environments, and ultimately achieve a level of control and dexterity comparable to that of natural arm movements.





CELEST Science of Learning Seminar Series



Friday, May 9, 2014 at 2:00pm



Boston University

677 Beacon Street

Auditorium, Room B02

Refreshments will be served after the talk in Room B03



For more information on upcoming events, visit http://celest.bu.edu
***********************************************************************************************************************


Sarah Swenson
Center for Computational Neuroscience and Neural Technology
Senior Program Coordinator
677 Beacon Street
Boston, MA 02215
swensons@bu.edu<mailto:swensons@bu.edu>

subject: Talk on "Mindfulness and Neurofeedback" - Fri 2/21 3pm - E14-633 - Prof Judson Brewer
bodyText:
Hey Misha -

Could be of interest to you.

Caroline

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Pattie Maes <pattie@media.mit.edu>
Date: Sat, Feb 15, 2014 at 3:03 PM
Subject: Talk on "Mindfulness and Neurofeedback" - Fri 2/21 3pm - E14-633 -
Prof Judson Brewer
To: msgs@media.mit.edu, ml-all@media.mit.edu


  Mindfulness and Neurofeedback, Friday 2/21 Professor Judson Brewer,
University of Massachusetts Medical School
  *Abstract*
Over the past decade, there has been an explosion of interest in how
contemplative practices such as meditation can inform science and how
science can inform these practices. Recent advances have begun to unravel
the mysteries of how mindfulness practice can affect learning processes
leading to positive habit change. Using evidence from clinical trials of
smoking cessation, this presentation will first map out how mindfulness
targets key components of operant conditioning pathways. It will then
detail neuroscientific findings from novice and expert meditators using
traditional and real-time fMRI to link the subjective experience of
effortless awareness that may be a key aspect of mindfulness, to regional
brain activity in the default mode network. It will conclude with a
discussion of how targeted neurofeedback may provide a “mental mirror” for
augmenting mindfulness training.

*Bio*
Judson Brewer MD PhD is the Director of Research at the Center for
Mindfulness and associate professor in medicine and psychiatry at UMass
Medical School. He also is adjunct faculty at Yale University, and a
research affiliate at MIT. A psychiatrist and internationally known expert
in mindfulness training for addictions, Brewer has developed and tested
novel mindfulness programs for addictions, including both in-person and
app-based treatments. He has also studied the underlying neural mechanisms
of mindfulness using standard and real-time fMRI, and is currently
translating these findings into clinical use. He has published numerous
peer-reviewed articles and book chapters, spoken at international
conferences, presented to the US President’s Office of National Drug
Control Policy, been featured at TEDx, Time magazine (top 100 new health
discoveries of 2013), Forbes, Businessweek, NPR and the BBC among others.
He writes an addiction blog for The Huffington Post.

It will conclude with a discussion of how targeted neurofeedback may provide a “mental mirror” for augmenting mindfulness training.

Bio
Judson Brewer MD PhD is the Director of Research at the Center for Mindfulness and associate professor in medicine and psychiatry at UMass Medical School. He also is adjunct faculty at Yale University, and a research affiliate at MIT. A psychiatrist and internationally known expert in mindfulness training for addictions, Brewer has developed and tested novel mindfulness programs for addictions, including both in-person and app-based treatments. He has also studied the underlying neural mechanisms of mindfulness using standard and real-time fMRI, and is currently translating these findings into clinical use. He has published numerous peer-reviewed articles and book chapters, spoken at international conferences, presented to the US President’s Office of National Drug Control Policy, been featured at TEDx, Time magazine (top 100 new health discoveries of 2013), Forbes, Businessweek, NPR and the BBC among others. He writes an addiction blog for The Huffington Post.

subject: Fwd: [Talk] Mon. May 5, 4pm, 32-D463 - Emanuel Parzen "LP Statistical Science (Nonparametric Modeling, Exploratory Big Data Analysis)"
bodyText:
Hi,

I thought you might interest this talk. I will go,might see you there.

 Best,

-- Andrés

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Kathleen Sullivan <kdsulliv@csail.mit.edu>
Date: Tue, Apr 29, 2014 at 3:50 PM
Subject: [Talk] Mon. May 5, 4pm, 32-D463 - Emanuel Parzen "LP Statistical
Science (Nonparametric Modeling, Exploratory Big Data Analysis)"
To:


 *LP Statistical Science (Nonparametric Modeling, Exploratory Big Data
Analysis)*
Speaker: Emanuel Parzen <http://www.stat.tamu.edu/%7Eeparzen/>, Department
of Statistics, Texas A&M University
Date: Monday, May 5
Time: 4:00pm – 5:00pm
Location: Star Conference Room, 32-D463
Host: Tomaso Poggio, CBMM, BCS, MIBR, CSAIL, LCSL

*Abstract*:  Statisticians in the 21st century can look forward to very
bright futures for the discipline and profession of statistics by solving
the important problem of teaching thousands statistical data scientist
aspirants, what are the fundamental methods of statistical learning. We are
developing a framework that unifies parametric and nonparametric models,
frequentist and Bayesian inference, small data and big data, beginning
courses that differ from traditional courses by teaching methods for simple
data in ways that extend to complex high dimensional data (similar to the
goal of teaching finite dimensional math in the notation that extend to
Hilbert space). To accomplish the above, a theory, called LP STATISTICAL
SCIENCE, is being developed by myself and Subhadeep (Deep) Mukhopadhyay
(Temple University Fox School of Business). The theory is unifying because
it applies to mixed data (variables which are discrete or continuous) and
to population and sample distributions. It practices "plug-in estimation"
computed for sample distributions by the same definitions used for
population distributions.

*Short Bio*:  Emanuel Parzen is a Distinguished Professor Emeritus, Dept.
of Statistics, Texas A&M University. He has served as an Assistant
Professor of Mathematical Statistics at Columbia, Professor of Statistics
at Stanford, a Leading Professor-Chairman of the Dept. of Statistics and a
Director of Statistical Science at the State University of New York at
Buffalo, and a Distinguished Professor at Texas A&M University. He has been
a Fellow at Imperial College London, IBM Systems Research Institute, the
Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences at Stanford, and a
Visiting Professor at the Sloan School of MIT, the Dept. of Statistics at
Harvard and the Dept. of Biostatistics at Harvard. Professor Parzen has
authored or coauthored over 120 papers and 6 books, on signal detection
theory, time series analysis and non-parametric statistics. He pioneered
the use of kernel density estimation (also known as the Parzen window in
his honor) and Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Spaces (RKHS) in statistics and
engineering. He has served on innumerable editorial boards and national
committees, and has organized several influential conferences and
workshops. He has been elected Fellow of the American Statistical
Association, the Institute of Mathematical Statistics and the American
Association for the Advancement of Science. In 1994, he was awarded the
prestigious Samuel S. Wilks Memorial Medal by the American Statistical
Association.

Relevant URL: http://lcsl.mit.edu/#/events/seminars

Open to: the general public

This talk is part of the LCSL "Machine Learning Seminar Series" organized
by the Laboratory for Computational and Statistical Learning (LCSL) (a
joint lab between MIT and the Italian Institute of Technology), and
coordinated with the Center for Brains, Minds and Machines (CBMM).

-- 
Kathleen D. Sullivan
Center Manager
Center for Brains, Minds and Machines (CBMM)
McGovern Institute for Brain Research at MIT
Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences
Office: MIT 46-5169A
(617) 253-0551


_______________________________________________
Bcs-talks mailing list
Bcs-talks@mit.edu
http://mailman.mit.edu/mailman/listinfo/bcs-talks




-- 
Andrés

subject: TOMORROW! 2PM: Christopher Pack, CompNet Seminar
bodyText:
UPCOMING EVENT: CompNet Seminar

A sensorimotor role for oscillations in visual cortex

Christopher Pack, McGill University
Oscillations are frequently observed in recordings of neural activity, including in local field potential (LFP) signals, where they probably represent network activity on a scale of a few hundred microns. At certain frequencies, LFP oscillations appear to modulate single-neuron excitability, suggesting that they provide a means of organizing perception through time. In this talk I will suggest that oscillations provide an interface between the oculomotor and visual systems. Recordings from multi-electrode arrays in V4 of macaque monkeys show that saccades shape the pattern of oscillatory activity across retinotopic space in such a way as to prioritize the processing of behaviorally relevant information.

Friday, May 2, 2014 at 2:00pm


Boston University
677 Beacon Street
Auditorium, Room B02
Boston, MA 02215
Refreshments to follow.

For more information on upcoming events, visit http://compnet.bu.edu

******************************************************************************************************************


Sarah Swenson
Center for Computational Neuroscience and Neural Technology
Senior Program Coordinator
677 Beacon Street
Boston, MA 02215
swensons@bu.edu<mailto:swensons@bu.edu>

subject: CompNet Seminar: Christopher Pack, Friday, May 2
bodyText:
Please save the date for this seminar

View this email in your browser (http://us7.campaign-archive2.com/?u=9b41f765c1353463edf9e18b2&id=0ea2d966e1&e=6ba7750962)

We are pleased to announce the following seminar at Boston University:

A Sensory Role for Oscillations in Visual Cortex
CompNet Seminar
Christopher Pack
McGill University
Oscillations are frequently observed in recordings of neural activity, including in local field potential (LEP) signals, where they probably represent network activity on a scale of a few hundred microns. At certain frequencies, LFP oscillations appear to modulate single-neuron excitability, suggesting that they provide a means of organizing perception through time. In this talk, I will suggest that oscillations provide an interface between the oculomotor and visual systems. Recordings from multi-electrode arrays in V4 of macaque monkeys show that saccades shape the pattern of oscillatory activity across retinotopic space in such a way as to prioritize the process of behaviorally relevant information.

Seminar Details

2:00 PM
Friday, May 2, 2014
Auditorium, Room B02
677 Beacon Street
Boston, MA 02215
Refreshments to follow.

subject: [speechlabbu] Fwd: FW: SPECIAL SEMINAR: NLM Lecture | Michael Long | How does the brain generate sequences for behavior? | Tuesday, April 29, 2014 @ 4PM
bodyText:
---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Joseph S Perkell <jperkell@mit.edu>
Date: Wed, Apr 23, 2014 at 5:02 PM
Subject: FW: SPECIAL SEMINAR: NLM Lecture | Michael Long | How does the
brain generate sequences for behavior? | Tuesday, April 29, 2014 @ 4PM
To: "Guenther, Frank H" <guenther@bu.edu>


 Hi Frank,

There might be some interest in this among your group members.

Cheers,

Joe

*From:* bcs-talks-bounces@MIT.EDU [mailto:bcs-talks-bounces@MIT.EDU] *On
Behalf Of *Dept of Brain and Cognitive Sciences
*Sent:* Wednesday, April 23, 2014 3:58 PM
*To:* bcs-all@MIT.EDU; bcs-talks@MIT.EDU
*Subject:* SPECIAL SEMINAR: NLM Lecture | Michael Long | How does the brain
generate sequences for behavior? | Tuesday, April 29, 2014 @ 4PM







 *Neurobiology of Learning and Memory Lecture (NLM)*



*How does the brain generate sequences for behavior?*

Dr. Michael Long

Tuesday, April 29, 2014 @ 4PM
Singleton Auditorium, 46-3002

*Host*: Edward Nieh



Complex motor sequences such as speaking are central to our everyday lives,
but little is known about the relevant microcircuitry enabling these
behaviors.  In the zebra finch, a dedicated cortical sequence-generating
nucleus known as HVC controls song production.  Using a range of
experimental techniques to manipulate and monitor circuit activity, we have
begun to establish a mechanistic understanding of the cellular and circuit
activity underlying premotor sequence generation in the zebra finch.
Specifically, we have uncovered the mechanisms by which network sparsity is
achieved and the role of recurrent sensory feedback in the maintenance of
premotor patterns.  Through initial investigations into mammalian vocal
production circuitry, we are attempting to generalize our findings across
systems.



*Michael Long’s* research focuses on understanding the mechanisms by which
neurons work together to enable skilled movements. Towards that end, he has
developed innovative approaches to monitor and manipulate motor-related
neural circuits underlying complex behavioral sequences.  His work extends
to a variety of model systems, including humans, songbirds, and a
wild-caught Costa Rican rodent species.

In his young career, Michael has received a number of awards and
fellowships including the Esther A. & Joseph Klingenstein Fellowship Award
in the Neurosciences, the Rita Allen Foundation Scholars Award, and the
Robertson Investigator Award from the New York Stem Cell Foundation. Dr.
Long received his PhD from Brown University, and he completed his
postdoctoral training in the McGovern Institute for Brain Research at MIT.













-- 
<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>

Neurobiology of Learning and Memory Lecture (NLM)

 

How does the brain generate sequences for behavior?

Dr. Michael Long

Tuesday, April 29, 2014 @ 4PM
Singleton Auditorium, 46-3002

Host: Edward Nieh

 

Complex motor sequences such as speaking are central to our everyday lives, but little is known about the relevant microcircuitry enabling these behaviors.  In the zebra finch, a dedicated cortical sequence-generating nucleus known as HVC controls song production.  Using a range of experimental techniques to manipulate and monitor circuit activity, we have begun to establish a mechanistic understanding of the cellular and circuit activity underlying premotor sequence generation in the zebra finch.  Specifically, we have uncovered the mechanisms by which network sparsity is achieved and the role of recurrent sensory feedback in the maintenance of premotor patterns.  Through initial investigations into mammalian vocal production circuitry, we are attempting to generalize our findings across systems.

 

Michael Long’s research focuses on understanding the mechanisms by which neurons work together to enable skilled movements. Towards that end, he has developed innovative approaches to monitor and manipulate motor-related neural circuits underlying complex behavioral sequences.  His work extends to a variety of model systems, including humans, songbirds, and a wild-caught Costa Rican rodent species. 

In his young career, Michael has received a number of awards and fellowships including the Esther A. & Joseph Klingenstein Fellowship Award in the Neurosciences, the Rita Allen Foundation Scholars Award, and the Robertson Investigator Award from the New York Stem Cell Foundation. Dr. Long received his PhD from Brown University, and he completed his postdoctoral training in the McGovern Institute for Brain Research at MIT.

subject: Data Analysis Group talk: Grid cells in primates
bodyText:
From Mark Kramer:

FYI:  Dr. Nathan Killian from MGH will speak at our data analysis lab
meeting on Friday.  He recently found grid cells in primate cortex - see
the Nature article here:
http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v491/n7426/full/nature11587.html

Time/Date:  3 PM, April 25
Location:  111 Cummington Mall, Boston, MA.  Room 241

Title:  Visual Memory in the Primate Entorhinal Cortex

Abstract:

The entorhinal cortex (EC) in the medial temporal lobe plays a critical
role in memory formation and is implicated in several neurological diseases
including temporal lobe epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease. Despite the known
importance of this brain region, deeper investigation of the normal
bioelectrical activity patterns of the EC in awake, behaving primates is
necessary. I recorded the activity of individual neurons and populations of
neurons in the EC of rhesus macaque monkeys during free-viewing of
photographs. The results of these experiments help to explain how primates
form memories of, and navigate through, the visual world. Neurons were
discovered in the EC that represent visual space with triangular grid
receptive fields. This property is similar to grid cells previously
described in the rodent EC, but here the neuronal responses relate to
viewing of remote space as opposed to representing the physical location of
the animal. Intermixed with spatial neurons were neurons that encoded
aspects of recognition memory. Interesting activity patterns related to
recognition memory were further present at the population level.
Synchronization within the gamma-band (30-140 Hz) in superficial layers of
the EC was modulated by stimulus novelty, while the strength of memory
formation modulated gamma-band synchronization in the deep layers and in
layer III. Furthermore, the strength of connectivity in the gamma-band
between different layers was correlated with the strength of memory
formation: deep to superficial power transfer was correlated with stronger
memory formation and superficial to deep transfer was correlated with
weaker memory formation. These findings support previous investigations of
hippocampal-entorhinal connectivity in the rodent and advance our
understanding of the functional circuitry of the medial temporal lobe
memory system.

-- 
You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "NaK short list" group.
To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to nak-short-list+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.
For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/d/optout.

From Mark Kramer:

FYI:  Dr. Nathan Killian from MGH will speak at our data analysis lab meeting on Friday.  He recently found grid cells in primate cortex - see the Nature article here:
http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v491/n7426/full/nature11587.html

Time/Date:  3 PM, April 25
Location:  111 Cummington Mall, Boston, MA.  Room 241

Title:  Visual Memory in the Primate Entorhinal Cortex

Abstract:

The entorhinal cortex (EC) in the medial temporal lobe plays a critical role in memory formation and is implicated in several neurological diseases including temporal lobe epilepsy and Alzheimer’s disease. Despite the known importance of this brain region, deeper investigation of the normal bioelectrical activity patterns of the EC in awake, behaving primates is necessary. I recorded the activity of individual neurons and populations of neurons in the EC of rhesus macaque monkeys during free-viewing of photographs. The results of these experiments help to explain how primates form memories of, and navigate through, the visual world. Neurons were discovered in the EC that represent visual space with triangular grid receptive fields. This property is similar to grid cells previously described in the rodent EC, but here the neuronal responses relate to viewing of remote space as opposed to representing the physical location of the animal. Intermixed with spatial neurons were neurons that encoded aspects of recognition memory. Interesting activity patterns related to recognition memory were further present at the population level. Synchronization within the gamma-band (30-140 Hz) in superficial layers of the EC was modulated by stimulus novelty, while the strength of memory formation modulated gamma-band synchronization in the deep layers and in layer III. Furthermore, the strength of connectivity in the gamma-band between different layers was correlated with the strength of memory formation: deep to superficial power transfer was correlated with stronger memory formation and superficial to deep transfer was correlated with weaker memory formation. These findings support previous investigations of hippocampal-entorhinal connectivity in the rodent and advance our understanding of the functional circuitry of the medial temporal lobe memory system.

--

subject: Friday JC (week 130). *1pm*, 3rd floor-- Does the LGN process orientation information?
bodyHtml:
Dear all,

        This Friday, Sam Ling, from the Department of Psychological & Brain Sciences at Boston University will present in our Friday journal club.

        Given the classical thought that LGN does not process orientation information, it should be a very stimulating talk. Below, please find the abstract that Sam provided for us:

Title: Does the LGN process orientation information?

Abstract: Ever since Hubel & Wiesel, the standard models for early vision have typically assumed that orientation selectivity first emerges in visual cortex, with little contribution from the retina and the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN).  This assumption was largely based on the idea that receptive fields the LGN and retina are concentric, and thus are incapable of coding orientation information.  A growing body of empirical results, however, indicates that the notion of circular ON-OFF receptive fields may be oversimplified: receptive fields within both the LGN and the retina have been shown to have a tendency to be elongated, in a manner that would support orientation-selective processing prior to cortex. I will provide a survey of the empirical literature examining this possibility, with the hope that this will spur discussion as to whether this has any ramifications for current models of visual processing.


        Hope to see you all.
        Arash

subject: NaK: WED, 4/2, 4pm
bodyText:
Wednesday, 4/2, 4pm, MCS241

Talker: Michelle M. McCarthy

Talk: Multiple time scale dynamics of excitation-induced pauses in globus
pallidus neurons

Abstract:
The basal ganglia consist of a set of subcortical nuclei that function in
coordination of movement, habit formation, and reward-based learning.
Dysfunction of the basal ganglia is associated with a host of neurologic
and psychiatric diseases including Parkinson's disease, Huntington's
disease, addiction and depression. The central nucleus of the BG is the
globus pallidus externus (GPe). Approximately half of GPe neurons regularly
display pauses in their spiking activity. Both the function and the
mechanism of these pauses are currently undetermined. Computational
modeling has identified a possible mechanism for these pauses. The
mechanism is excitation-induced and depends on two slow membrane currents
with widely different time scales. The proposed mechanism has readily
apparent functional implications for the larger basal ganglia network. We
discuss approaches to characterizing the key dynamical interactions that
promote pauses in order to identify specific physiological conditions
mediating both function and dysfunction in these networks.

--

bodyHtml:
Wednesday, 4/2, 4pm, MCS241

Talker: Michelle M. McCarthy

Talk: Multiple time scale dynamics of excitation-induced pauses in globus pallidus neurons

Abstract:
The basal ganglia consist of a set of subcortical nuclei that function in coordination of movement, habit formation, and reward-based learning. Dysfunction of the basal ganglia is associated with a host of neurologic and psychiatric diseases including Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease, addiction and depression. The central nucleus of the BG is the globus pallidus externus (GPe). Approximately half of GPe neurons regularly display pauses in their spiking activity. Both the function and the mechanism of these pauses are currently undetermined. Computational modeling has identified a possible mechanism for these pauses. The mechanism is excitation-induced and depends on two slow membrane currents with widely different time scales. The proposed mechanism has readily apparent functional implications for the larger basal ganglia network. We discuss approaches to characterizing the key dynamical interactions that promote pauses in order to identify specific physiological conditions mediating both function and dysfunction in these networks.

subject: [CRC] Save the date:  CRC Minisympoium April 16, 2014
bodyText:
Dear CRCers,

Now that we have held a successful retreat, it is time for the next event!
We are holding a Mini-Symposium on the afternoon of april 16, titled

"Frontiers in Non-invasive Brain Stimulation"

Wednesday April 16, 2014 at 1 pm
Boston University Photonics Center 209
8 St. Mary's Street
Boston, MA 02215

Registration is 1:00 and talks start at 1:15.  There is a reception after
the 4 talks, with a break in the middle.  The speakers are:

Alvaro Pascual-Leone, MD, PhD, Professor of Neurology at Harvard Medical
School; Director of the Berenson-Allen Center for Noninvasive Brain
Stimulation; Program Director of the Harvard-Thorndike Clinical Research
Unit; and an Attending Neurologist at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center

Title: "Characterizing and guiding brain networks with noninvasive brain
stimulation"

Lucas Parra, Herbert Kayser Professor of Biomedical Engineering.
The City College of The City University of New York

Title: TBA

Tommi Raij, Assistant Professor of Radiology, Harvard Medical School
Assistant in Neuroscience, Massachusetts General Hospital TMS Core
Director, Martinos Center

Title: TBA

Noah Phillip, MD Butler Hospital / Providence VA Center for Neurorestoration and Neurotechnology
Department of Psychiatry and Human Behavior
Warren Alpert Medical School of Brown University

Title: "Clinical Implications of Frequency Dependent Neuromodulation."

4:30 - 6:00 pm Discussion/Reception

-------------------

As usual, WE NEED YOU TO REGISTER so we can get enough delicious food for
the break and reception.  Please email xiaoshi@bu.edu.

This is open to the public.  As soon as we get the other titles, we will
send out a flyer.  Feel free to invite friends, neighbors, colleagues...

Looking forward to seeing y'all there!

Best
Nancy

--

subject: Friday JC (week 129). *1pm*, 3rd floor--  Neuronal Representation by Eric Schwartz
bodyHtml:
Dear all,

        This Friday, at 1 pm, 3rd floor, Eric will host our Friday-JC.
        I strongly encourage the current and past students of CN530 to join us; as well, highly recommended to all.

        The abstract of Eric’s talk follows:


During the past 15 years, the von der Heyt lab has generated a series of extremely interesting papers suggesting that
many neurons in primate V2 respond to not only to contrast derivatives (as in V1, LGN, and retina) but also to
"boundary ownership". This amounts to a form of structured "edge" in which "ownership" of a nearby "shape"
is explicitly encoded in the neuronal response. In this meeting, this finding will be discussed in the larger context of
the problem of “Neuronal Representation".  The various theories of representation that have been considered range over
the single cell feature extraction (grandmother cell), Gestalt ideas of "one-to-one" representation, Gibsonian ideas
of "perception-action", topographic representation (via maps/columns), and von der Heydt's "boundary ownership".
The discussion will focus on these various conceptual frameworks, and, in particular, von der Heydt's apparent rejection of
the notion of a surface based representation  (neo-Gestalt?) in favor of a pure, but structured, "edge" representation.

An example of a recent "retinex" solution will be shown, in order to illustrate the difficulty with this idea, and to make explicit what an
"edge" versus "surface" representation actually "looks" like, and the problematic, though intriguing nature of some of von der Heydt's
thinking in this area.

        Hope to see you all,
        Arash
p.s. check out a few attached PDFs

============================
Arash Yazdanbakhsh, MD, PhD,
Research Assistant Professor,
Computational Neuroscience and Neural Technology (CompNet)
Program in Cognitive and Neural Systems, Boston University
Center of Excellence for Learning in Education, Science and Technology
http://cns.bu.edu/~yazdan/
============================

subject: Reminder: NaK meeting: **3:30pm** today
bodyText:
> 3:30pm (30 min early!), Wednesday (today), 2/26, MCS241
>
> (Head to the CRC dinner afterwards!)
>
> Ben Polletta presents:
>
> Ketamine-Induced ~140 Hz Oscillations in Nucleus Accumbens
>
> I'll present a literature review on the so-called high frequency
> oscillations (HFOs) observed in the nucleus accumbens (NAC) with NMDAR
> blockade. After a brief review of the structure and hypothesized functions
> of the NAC, I'll talk about the phenomenology and pharmacology of
> ketamine-induced NAC HFOs. Then I'll review some modeling results with
> relevance to striatal circuits, and we'll do our best to work our way
> around to mechanistic hypotheses regarding the generation of HFOs in the
> presence of NMDAR antagonists.
>

--

bodyHtml:
3:30pm (30 min early!), Wednesday (today), 2/26, MCS241

(Head to the CRC dinner afterwards!)

Ben Polletta presents:

Ketamine-Induced ~140 Hz Oscillations in Nucleus Accumbens

I'll present a literature review on the so-called high frequency oscillations (HFOs) observed in the nucleus accumbens (NAC) with NMDAR blockade. After a brief review of the structure and hypothesized functions of the NAC, I'll talk about the phenomenology and pharmacology of ketamine-induced NAC HFOs. Then I'll review some modeling results with relevance to striatal circuits, and we'll do our best to work our way around to mechanistic hypotheses regarding the generation of HFOs in the presence of NMDAR antagonists.

--

subject: [CRC] CRC dinner meeting,** Feb 26 **
bodyText:
Dear All,

Most of you have probably forgotten that our first dinner meeting of the
academic year is next week, Feb 26 at MIT at 6PM.  The speaker will be
Mike Hasselmo.

The next email will have the title and room. Mike, please send me a title.

Thanks to all,
Nancy


On Tue, 18 Feb 2014, Nancy Kopell wrote:

>
> Hi CRCers
>
> I will continue to nudge you about contacting Xiaoshi until we reach
> threshold - lots of you have signed in, but there are a lot more out there
> who have been putting off this little task.
>
> We also need to hear from more people who can present posters (recycled
> ones are welcome).  I will soon get back to those of you who have
> volunteered for the short talks - many thanks!
>
> I feel like one of those annoying people on WGBH reminding you that the
> sooner you give the less they will nag you in the future.  To paraphrase
> Nancy Reagon, "Just Say Yes".
>
> Best
> Nancy (the Nudge)
>
>
>
>
> On Sun, 2 Feb 2014, Nancy Kopell wrote:
>
> >
> > Dear All,
> >
> > March 17 may seem like a long way off, but actually, it is just around the
> > corner.  We have heard from a few of you, but we need to hear from more.
> > We especially need to hear from those of you who would like/can be
> > persuaded to give a short talk (20 mins + questions) or a poster
> > (recycling is fine).
> >
> > So celebrate Ground Hog Day by insuring that we will have still another
> > wonderful Retreat!
> >
> > Best
> > Nancy
> >
> >
> > On Fri, 17 Jan 2014, Nancy Kopell wrote:
> >
> > >
> > > Dear CRCers,
> > >
> > > Well, we have encountered our first foulup of the new year (mea culpa),
> > > with a happy resolution.  The old date for the retreat had important
> > > conflicts.  We have now found a new date: March 17, with the retreat to be
> > > held on the Charles River Campus at BU.  Please mark the date, and tell
> > > Xiaoshi a) if you are coming and b) if you would like to give a talk or
> > > poster.
> > >
> > > In the mean time, other events have firmed up:
> > >
> > > This semester there will be a series of group sessions on practical topics
> > > in scientific programming and computation. Our kick off session is on
> > > **January 29th**, at either 2pm or 4pm, TBD, during which we will discuss
> > > how we program our biophysical neural models and the structure of that
> > > code. A pre-session on **January 22nd at 2pm** will cover using revision
> > > control and code repositories, e.g. GitHub. Session topics will follow the
> > > group's interests, and may include a comparison of programming languages
> > > for scientific computing, a review of the plus/minuses of different
> > > standard biophysical models, coding best practices, etc. The group will
> > > meet approximately every other Wednesday at 2pm. All meetings will be at
> > > BU, 111 Cummington St, Room 241, unless that room turns out to be too
> > > small for those interested.  Please contact Caroline Moore-Kochlacs if
> > > you plan to come so we can get an appropriate room.
> > >
> > > Our first dinner speaker will be Mike Hasselmo on Feb 26.  That will be
> > > 6:00 at MIT, room to be announced.
> > >
> > > Onward and sideways,
> > > Nancy
> > >

1:30-2:30 p.m.
BUSM Housman Building, R-103

Olivier Kocher, PhD
Department of Pathology, Harvard Medical School


Feb. 26 Schwartz Center Connections Program
This message is from: Karin Sloan, MD Karin.Sloan@bmc.org 
Location: BUSM Evans Building Wilkins Boardroom, Room 120
Wednesday, Feb. 26
8-9 a.m.
BUSM Evans Building, Wilkins Boardroom, Room 120

"Improving Multidisciplinary Communication in Diagnosing and Caring for Patients with Cancer"

The third in a series of three case-based discussions, this program will bring together different disciplines to talk about key communication issues that leave cancer patients vulnerable to errors and adverse outcomes.

1 p.m.
BUSM Instructional Building, L-504

"Investigating Respiratory Syncytial Virus Transcription: Evidence for Alternative Initiation Events and Small RNA Synthesis"
Chadene Tremaglio
Department of Microbiology, BUSM


Feb. 27 CTSI Seminar
This message is from: Tasha Coughlin/Communications Coordinator tawatson@bu.edu 
Location: Crosstown Building, 801 Massachusetts Ave. Room 335
Thursday, Feb. 27
Noon-1 p.m.
Crosstown Building, 801 Massachusetts Ave., Room 335

"Study Electronic Data Capture: StudyTRAX "
John Putzke, PhD, MSPH
Founder, ScienceTrax

This presentation is intended for researchers considering the use of StudyTRAX, an integrated survey and study management electronic data capture (EDC) system. Attendees will learn about functionality, application development, product roadmap and support model.

Audio Conference: 1-877-890-9502
Participant Code: 8018012
To join the meeting virtually: http://bumedical.adobeconnect.com/ctsi-studytrax/


Feb. 27 All About Renting in Boston
This message is from: Barbara Attianese ohr@bu.edu 638-5125
Location: BUSM Instructional Building and BUSM Evans Building L-112 and Keefer Auditorium
Thursday, Feb. 27
Noon-1:30 p.m.
BUSM Instructional Building, Room L-112
5:30-7 p.m.
BUSM Evans Building, Keefer Auditorium
Pizza will be provided

"All About Renting in Boston"
Steven Handler
Beacon Realty Properties LLC

Have all your questions about renting an apartment in Boston answered, from beginning a search to signing a lease. RSVP to ohr@bu.edu by 5 p.m., Feb. 25.


Feb. 28 Third Annual Pharmaceuticals Program Symposium
This message is from: Madeleine Kuhn mkuhn@bu.edu 302-753-6767
Location: BUSM A Building Bakst Auditorium
Friday, Feb. 28
1-7 p.m.
BUSM A Building, Bakst Auditorium

Feb. 28 Exploring Gender Violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) Panel Discussion
This message is from: Kara Peterson  
Location: 670 Albany St. First Floor Auditorium
Friday, Feb. 28
8:30 a.m.-1 p.m. (breakfast 8:30, panel discussion 9)
670 Albany St., First Floor Auditorium

"Exploring Gender Violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) Panel Discussion"

DRC has been referred to as the “rape capital of the world", yet measuring the magnitude and impact of gender violence remains difficult. Human rights abuses in the Congo have been covered widely by the media, but it is hard to know if we have been hearing the full story. BU and the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting will convene a panel of journalists, public health experts, artists and activists to discuss the challenges of accurate, nuanced reporting on the DRC.

For more information or to RSVP for this discussion, visit http://www.bu.edu/sph/news-events/signature-events/global-health-reporting-gender-violence-in-democratic-republic-of-congo.

Research Study: PRESTO Fertility Study
This message is from: Lauren Wise bupresto@bu.edu 617-734-6006 Ext. 590
Women aged 21-45 years are invited to participate in an Internet-based fertility study at BU. PRESTO (PREgnancy STudy Online) is a 12-month study that will examine whether selected lifestyle factors can affect the chances of successful pregnancy. Female participants will be asked to complete one 30-40 minute online questionnaire at enrollment, and then shorter 10-15 minute questionnaires every two months or until pregnancy occurs. An optional online dietary questionnaire will be emailed to the female participant 10 days after enrollment. Female participants also will be given the opportunity to invite their partners to complete a 10 minute questionnaire via the Internet. Half of female participants will be randomized to receive a complimentary subscription to FertilityFriend.com. Interested individuals should visit the PRESTO study website: http://presto.bu.edu or contact Lauren Wise at bupresto@bu.edu 617-734-6006 Ext. 590.


Research Study: Meditation and Graduate Student Wellness
This message is from: Erin Anderson ebanders@bu.edu 
Participate as a citizen scientist in a research study designed to assess the impact of mindfulness meditation training on graduate students. Participants may experience reduced stress, improved physical well being, and improved coping skills. No meditation experience necessary. Participants will be compensated with meals at each session and a $10 gift card for completion of the study. Contact Erin Anderson at ebanders@bu.edu for more information.

subject: TODAY 2PM! Olaf Sporns, Science of Learning Seminar
bodyText:
Network Neuroscience: From the Connectome to Brain Dynamics and Function

Olaf Sporns, Indiana University



Recent advances in network science have greatly increased our understanding of the structure and function of many networked systems, ranging from transportation networks, to social networks, the internet, ecosystems, and biochemical and gene transcription pathways.  Network approaches are also increasingly applied to the brain, at several levels of scale from cells to entire nervous systems. Early studies in this emerging field of brain connectomics have focused on mapping brain network topology and identifying some of its characteristic features, including small world attributes, modularity and hubs. More recently, the emphasis has shifted towards linking brain network topology to brain dynamics, the patterns of functional interactions that emerge from spontaneous and evoked neuronal activity.  I will give an overview of recent work characterizing the structure of complex brain networks, with particular emphasis on studies demonstrating how the network topology of the connectome constrains and shapes its capacity to process and integrate information.





CELEST Science of Learning Seminar Series



Friday, February 21, 2014 at 2:00pm



Boston University

677 Beacon Street

Auditorium, Room B02

Refreshments will be served after the talk in Room B03



For more information on upcoming events, visit http://celest.bu.edu
***********************************************************************************************************************


Sarah Swenson
Center for Computational Neuroscience and Neural Technology
Senior Program Coordinator
677 Beacon Street
Boston, MA 02215
swensons@bu.edu<mailto:swensons@bu.edu>

More recently, the emphasis has shifted towards linking brain network topology to brain dynamics, the patterns of functional interactions that emerge from spontaneous and evoked neuronal activity.  I will give an overview of recent work characterizing the structure of complex brain networks, with particular emphasis on studies demonstrating how the network topology of the connectome constrains and shapes its capacity to process and integrate information.

The BUSM Historical Society is proud to sponsor this presentation by Joe Blansfield, NP, Trauma Program Manager at BMC. He will discuss how Boston City Hospital managed burn victims from the 1942 fire that had killed 492 people at Boston’s Cocoanut Grove nightclub. This deadly event led to the reform of safety standards and codes across the country, and major changes in the treatment and rehabilitation of burn victims.

Research Study: PRESTO Fertility Study
This message is from: Lauren Wise bupresto@bu.edu 617-734-6006 Ext. 590
Women aged 21-45 years are invited to participate in an Internet-based fertility study at BU. PRESTO (PREgnancy STudy Online) is a 12-month study that will examine whether selected lifestyle factors can affect the chances of successful pregnancy. Female participants will be asked to complete one 30-40 minute online questionnaire at enrollment, and then shorter 10-15 minute questionnaires every two months or until pregnancy occurs. An optional online dietary questionnaire will be emailed to the female participant 10 days after enrollment. Female participants also will be given the opportunity to invite their partners to complete a 10 minute questionnaire via the Internet. Half of female participants will be randomized to receive a complimentary subscription to FertilityFriend.com. Interested individuals should visit the PRESTO study website: http://presto.bu.edu or contact Lauren Wise at bupresto@bu.edu 617-734-6006 Ext. 590.


Research Study: Weight Loss
This message is from: Alexandra Pitkin, RD/Research Dietitian alexandra.pitkin@bmc.org 638-5904
Pivotal Aspiration Therapy with Adjusted Lifestyle (PATHWAY) is a multi-center, randomized, controlled, open-label, 52-week trial. The purpose of this research study is to test the effectiveness of a new investigational medical device, the AspireAssist Aspiration Therapy System, for treatment of obesity. Aspiration therapy reduces the calories absorbed by the body by allowing one to drain a portion of one’s stomach contents after a meal.

To participate, you must be seeking weight loss and have had failed attempts to successfully lose weight. There will be up to a total of 17 study visits during a 52-week period. Visits will include exams such as bone density composition, blood work, EKG and lifestyle therapy sessions.

Inclusion Criteria Includes:
- Men and women age 21-65
- Obese (BMI 35-55)
- Failed attempts to lose weight
- Stable weight
- Women of child bearing potential willing to use birth control

For more information, please contact Alexandra Pitkin, RD at 638-5904 or Alexandra.Pitkin@bmc.org.


Research Study: Hypertension
This message is from: Research Fellow  
The Cardiovascular Division at BMC is seeking volunteers with high blood pressure on stable blood pressure treatment, ages 21-70, to participate in an NIH-sponsored research study investigating the effects of a new dietary supplement on cardiovascular health. Eligible participants will undergo a focused physical exam and a blood draw as part of the screening procedure. Compensation will be provided.

For more information or to find out if you are eligible, please contact study coordinator Raji Santhanakrishnan, MD, at rajis@bu.edu or 638-8754.


Research Study: Meditation and Graduate Student Wellness
This message is from: Erin Anderson ebanders@bu.edu 
Participate as a citizen scientist in a research study designed to assess the impact of mindfulness meditation training on graduate students. Participants may experience reduced stress, improved physical well being, and improved coping skills. No meditation experience necessary. Participants will be compensated with meals at each session and a $10 gift card for completion of the study. Contact Erin Anderson at ebanders@bu.edu for more information.

subject: Friday, February 21st: Olaf Sporns, Science of Learning Seminar
bodyText:
Network Neuroscience: From the Connectome to Brain Dynamics and Function

Olaf Sporns, Indiana University



Recent advances in network science have greatly increased our understanding of the structure and function of many networked systems, ranging from transportation networks, to social networks, the internet, ecosystems, and biochemical and gene transcription pathways.  Network approaches are also increasingly applied to the brain, at several levels of scale from cells to entire nervous systems. Early studies in this emerging field of brain connectomics have focused on mapping brain network topology and identifying some of its characteristic features, including small world attributes, modularity and hubs. More recently, the emphasis has shifted towards linking brain network topology to brain dynamics, the patterns of functional interactions that emerge from spontaneous and evoked neuronal activity.  I will give an overview of recent work characterizing the structure of complex brain networks, with particular emphasis on studies demonstrating how the network topology of the connectome constrains and shapes its capacity to process and integrate information.





CELEST Science of Learning Seminar Series



Friday, February 21, 2014 at 2:00pm



Boston University

677 Beacon Street

Auditorium, Room B02

Refreshments will be served after the talk in Room B03



For more information on upcoming events, visit http://celest.bu.edu
***********************************************************************************************************************


Sarah Swenson
Center for Computational Neuroscience and Neural Technology
Senior Program Coordinator
677 Beacon Street
Boston, MA 02215
swensons@bu.edu<mailto:swensons@bu.edu>

Recent advances in network science have greatly increased our understanding of the structure and function of many networked systems, ranging from transportation networks, to social networks, the internet, ecosystems, and biochemical and gene transcription pathways.  Network approaches are also increasingly applied to the brain, at several levels of scale from cells to entire nervous systems. Early studies in this emerging field of brain connectomics have focused on mapping brain network topology and identifying some of its characteristic features, including small world attributes, modularity and hubs. More recently, the emphasis has shifted towards linking brain network topology to brain dynamics, the patterns of functional interactions that emerge from spontaneous and evoked neuronal activity.  I will give an overview of recent work characterizing the structure of complex brain networks, with particular emphasis on studies demonstrating how the network topology of the connectome constrains and shapes its capacity to process and integrate information.

subject: Tomorrow: Friday JC (week 128). *2.30pm*, 3rd floor--  Modulated DPSS, of interest to both Vision and Auditory folks
bodyHtml:
Reminder for our tomorrow JC.
        Kyle Lepage will present his contribution in DPSS and introduce us with the idea and basic/practical examples in Vision and Auditory System (please see below).
        Hope to see you all,
        Arash




On Feb 10, 2014, at 11:11 PM, "Yazdanbakhsh, Arash" <yazdan@bu.edu> wrote:

>       Dear all,
>
>       This week, our Friday JC, hosts Kyle, who will present his research on discrete prolate spheroidal sequences (DPSSs).
>
>       Below please find Kyle’s abstract for his talk:
>
> The discrete prolate spheroidal sequences (DPSSs) are a set of pair-wise orthogonal sequences, each of which is optimally signal-energy-concentrated within a specified frequency interval.  They have recently been suggested as system stimuli for the purpose of determining input-output connections for a class of  nonlinear, multiple-in, multiple-out (MIMO) systems (Lepage & Ching, submitted, 2014).
>
> Following a review of the properties of the discrete prolate spheroidal sequences (DPSSs), I will motivate their use for system identification. The discussion will consist of simple examples and intuitive arguments.  Time permitting I will present results bounding system identification performance in terms of the number of system inputs, the DPSS bandwidth parameter, the energy concentrations of the input DPSSs and system specific quantities derived from the generalized, frequency-domain system response.
>
>
>       Highly recommended; hope to see you all.
>       Best wishes,
>       Arash
>
>

subject: Neurobiology Search Seminar: Jeffrey Gavornik, Thursday Feb 6
bodyText:
Please save the date for this seminar

View this email in your browser (http://us7.campaign-archive2.com/?u=9b41f765c1353463edf9e18b2&id=4bad9515d7&e=6ba7750962)

We are pleased to announce the following seminar at Boston University:

Learning When to See What: Spatiotemporal Sequence Recognition and Prediction in Primary Visual Cortex
Department of Biology
Neurobiology Search Seminar
Dr. Jeffrey Gavornik, PhD
MIT, The Picower Institute for Learning and Memory
Abstract: Sensory stimuli reach the brain as temporal sequences of spatial activation patterns driven by external events. Through experience, the brain learns to use this noisy and incomplete data to infer and predict the current and future states of its surroundings and to generate appropriate behaviors. Despite the fundamental importance of this ability as it relates to executive behavior and cognition, little is known about its neural basis. This talk will present evidence that visual experience can encode specific predictive spatiotemporal sequence representations in primary visual cortex (V1). These findings support the hypothesis that temporal sequence coding is a fundamental ability of neocortical circuits, not a specialization of higher cortical association areas, and suggest that V1 can be used to mechanistically study how the brain uses past experience to make "intelligent guesses" based on limited information.

Seminar Details

4:00 PM
Thursday, February 6, 2014
Room 103
24 Cummington Mall, LSEB

Wine and Cheese Reception following seminar in LSEB Lobby

subject: Neurobiology Search Candidate: Dr. David Gire, Monday Feb 3
bodyText:
Please save the date for this seminar

View this email in your browser (http://us7.campaign-archive2.com/?u=9b41f765c1353463edf9e18b2&id=bf4bb9b35f&e=6ba7750962)

We are pleased to announce the following seminar at Boston University:

From Circuits to Behavior: New Concepts in Olfactory Processing
Department of Biology
Neurobiology Search Seminar
Dr. David Gire
Harvard Univeristy
Abstract: The complex patterns of neural activity in our brains do not recreate every detail of the external world, but rather efficiently and adaptively represent behaviorally relevant information derived from a constant stream of sensory input. This is particularly noticeable in the case of olfaction, since a smell is seldom experienced without a rich collection of learned associations. In this talk, I will present studies in the olfactory system that demonstrate both the neural codes used to efficiently represent behaviorally important information as well as the neural circuit mechanisms that support these codes. These studies provide new insights into the neural mechanisms through which sensory stimuli are combined with behavioral associations to generate efficient sensory codes in behaving animals.

Seminar Details

4:00 PM
Monday, February 3, 2014
Room 103
24 Cummington Mall, LSEB

Wine and Cheese Reception following seminar in LSEB Lobby

subject: Cognitive Neuroscience Seminar
bodyText:
Please save the date and plan to attend this important seminar.

View this email in your browser (http://us7.campaign-archive1.com/?u=9b41f765c1353463edf9e18b2&id=bd3b21e072&e=6ba7750962)


** We are pleased to announce the following seminar at Boston University:
------------------------------------------------------------


** The Cognitive Neuroscience of Remembering
------------------------------------------------------------


** Anthony Wagner, Stanford University
------------------------------------------------------------
Declarative memory permits an organism to bridge past and present, providing experience-dependent predictive information that informs current decisions and actions. Declarative memory critically depends on the medial temporal lobe (MTL) -- the hippocampal formation and surrounding parahippocampal gyrus -- as well as on interactions between the MTL and other cortical and subcortical structures. Recent progress in understanding human MTL function has come from the application of distributed pattern analyses of functional MRI data. In this talk, I will discuss how such analyses can be leveraged to delineate (a) the distinct computations subserved by MTL cortex and hippocampus in recognition memory, (b) the relationship between hippocampal and cortical processes at encoding and retrieval, and (c) the role of hippocampal-dependent pattern completion in across-event integration.

Seminar Details:

Friday, September 20, 2013 at 2:00pm
677 Beacon Street
Auditorium, Room B02
Refreshments will be served after the talk in Room B03

For more information on upcoming events, visit http://www.us7.list-manage1.com/track/click?u=9b41f765c1353463edf9e18b2&id=7b1d9ce5c6&e=6ba7750962

Declarative memory permits an organism to bridge past and present, providing experience-dependent predictive information that informs current decisions and actions. Declarative memory critically depends on the medial temporal lobe (MTL) -- the hippocampal formation and surrounding parahippocampal gyrus -- as well as on interactions between the MTL and other cortical and subcortical structures. Recent progress in understanding human MTL function has come from the application of distributed pattern analyses of functional MRI data. In this talk, I will discuss how such analyses can be leveraged to delineate (a) the distinct computations subserved by MTL cortex and hippocampus in recognition memory, (b) the relationship between hippocampal and cortical processes at encoding and retrieval, and (c) the role of hippocampal-dependent pattern completion in across-event integration.

Auditorium, Room B02
Refreshments will be served after the talk in Room B03

Sept. 18 Schwartz Center Connections Program: Improving Multidisciplinary Communication in Diagnosing and Caring for Patients with Cancer
This message is from: Karin Sloan  
Location: Crosstown Building Room 2127
Wednesday, Sept. 18
8-9 a.m.
Crosstown Building, Room 2127

"Schwartz Center Connections Program: Improving Multidisciplinary Communication in Diagnosing and Caring for Patients with Cancer"

This is the first in a series of three case-based discussions. Are we really too busy to talk to each other? Do our communication systems support dialogue about mutual patients? How well do we and our patients understand who is responsible for maintaining continuity of follow-up to prevent lapses in care?

This new program will bring together different disciplines to talk with each other about key communication issues that leave patients vulnerable to errors and adverse outcomes. We’ll bring together primary care, oncology, radiation oncology, and other related specialty clinicians and team members to begin these important conversations.

Save the dates for future sessions, Dec. 18 and Jan. 22, 8-9 a.m. This program meets the criteria of the Massachusetts Board of Registration in Medicine for 1 hour of risk management study.

The BU Institute for Philosophy and Religion will explore important philosophical, religious, and literary aspects of suffering. Please join Dean Karen Antman, MD (view profile), and members of the Boston University Medical Campus for a dedication and reception to celebrate recently restored historical pieces at the School of Medicine and Medical Campus. Recent improvements include the newly created picnic area on Talbot Green, a wonderful display of BUSM artifacts and artwork on the first floor of the Main Instructional Building, and the refurbished marble fountain in front of the Medical School. Sept. 26 and 27 National Pediatric Innovation Summit and Awards 2013: Taking on Tomorrow
This message is from: Communications Office  
Location: The Seaport Hotel, 200 Seaport Blvd., Boston
Thursday and Friday, Sept. 26 and 27
8 a.m.-7:15 p.m. on Thursday and 7:30 a.m.-2:30 p.m. on Friday
The Seaport Hotel, 200 Seaport Blvd., Boston

BMC is excited to partner with Boston Children’s Hospital for the National Pediatric Innovation Summit and Awards 2013: Taking on Tomorrow. By focusing on key areas such as autism, genomics, patient/family empowerment and innovation acceleration, the goal is to open a dynamic dialogue to promote the translation of research and clinical innovations into new products and standards of care to benefit patients. An exciting schedule of events features panels, discussions and presentations by some of the top thought leaders in medicine, industry and science.

Taking on Tomorrow will feature keynote presentations by Jeffrey Leiden, MD, PhD, the CEO of Vertex Pharmaceuticals; Atul Gawande, MD, a surgeon at Brigham and Women’s Hospital, staff writer for the New Yorker magazine and New York Times best-selling author; and MIT’s David H. Koch Institute Professor Robert S. Langer, PhD.

To register and view a full schedule of events, visit http://www.bostonchildrensinnovationsummit.org/.

Oct. 15 Deadline for Proposal Request
This message is from: Office of Communications  
The BU Center for Finance, Law & Policy is Issuing a Request for Proposals (RFP) that answers the following question: in the aftermath of the financial crisis, where do we go from here? Do you have a novel idea for how to better address financial risk? Or do you have an idea for research, a conference, or other project that will contribute to the ongoing discussions about financial reform or related issues?

The BU Center for Finance, Law and Policy invites you to submit a brief proposal (no more than 4 pages) for interdisciplinary and collaborative research, education or other initiatives. This opportunity is open to BU faculty, staff and graduate students.

Possibilities include but are not limited to:
- Seed projects to explore novel ideas
- Unusual and creative collaborative projects
- Special events, workshops or symposia exploring promising interdisciplinary approaches to finance, financial regulation or risk management
- Hosting and supporting visitors collaborating with BU researchers
- Financial literacy initiatives and approaches to reach “unbanked” communities
- Housing finance alternatives
- Methods for measuring, monitoring and controlling systemic risk
- Regulatory reform

The deadline for submissions is Oct 15. For submission guidelines visit http://www.bu.edu/bucflp/rfp/.


Oct. 21 RAD Self-Defense Class at BUMC
This message is from: Office of Communications  
Location: Solomon Carter Fuller Building, 85 East Newton St.
Begins Monday, Oct. 21
Five week course on Mondays
4:30-7:30 p.m.
Solomon Carter Fuller Building, 85 East Newton St.

Rape Aggression Defense (RAD), a self-defense program specifically for women desiring to physically protect themselves against rape and other forms of violence, is being offered on the Medical Campus. The fee is $10 per person. Sign up online or visit us for more information at http://www.bu.edu/police/services/RAD/

The RAD system is a realistic self-defense program of defensive tactics, techniques and education. It is a comprehensive course for women that follows a progression from awareness, prevention, risk reduction and avoidance to basic self-defense participation. The course includes an easy to read and well-illustrated student manual. This manual outlines the entire physical self-defense program and can be a reference for continued personal growth. The course is taught by BU Police RAD-certified instructors over twenty hours.

Research Study: Yoga for Depression
This message is from: Chris Streeter, MD yogast@.bu.edu 638-8046
Location: Solomon Carter Fuller Building 915A
BUSM is conducting a research study to evaluate the effect of yoga postures and breathing practices on mild to moderate depression. If you are depressed and want to participate in a study that does not include anti-depressant medications, you may be eligible to participate. Subjects are compensated for their time. Please contact us at 638-8046 or yogast@bu.edu for more information.

subject: Friday, September 20: Anthony Wagner, Science of Learning Seminar
bodyText:
The cognitive neuroscience of remembering

Anthony Wagner, Stanford University



Declarative memory permits an organism to bridge past and present, providing experience-dependent predictive information that informs current decisions and actions. Declarative memory critically depends on the medial temporal lobe (MTL) -- the hippocampal formation and surrounding parahippocampal gyrus -- as well as on interactions between the MTL and other cortical and subcortical structures. Recent progress in understanding human MTL function has come from the application of distributed pattern analyses of functional MRI data. In this talk, I will discuss how such analyses can be leveraged to delineate (a) the distinct computations subserved by MTL cortex and hippocampus in recognition memory, (b) the relationship between hippocampal and cortical processes at encoding and retrieval, and (c) the role of hippocampal-dependent pattern completion in across-event integration.





CELEST Science of Learning Seminar Series



Friday, September 20, 2013 at 2:00pm



Boston University

677 Beacon Street

Auditorium, Room B02

> > > The next dinner presentation will be given by Josh Berke.  Title and
> > > abstract are below. If you would like to join in on informal conversations
> > > with Josh the afternoon before and/or the morning after his talk, please
> > > let me know.

> > > This event will be in the McGovern Seminar Room 46-3189, 6:00PM April 16
> > >
> > > Seeya there!
> > >
> > > Best
> > > Nancy
> > > ---------------
> > > No Going Back Now: Basal Ganglia Dynamics in the Selection and Suppression of Actions.
> > >
> > > Even when sensory cues are clear, the time taken to initiate a response is
> > > highly variable. Much of this variability reflects the dynamically varying
> > > state of cortical-basal ganglia networks at the time of sensory input,
> > > including dopaminergic modulation of striatal microcircuitry. I will
> > > discuss some recent results from ongoing studies of basal ganglia function
> > > during decision-making, using electrophysiological and voltammetric
> > > methods. Some areas of particular current interest are how the striatum
> > > approaches a "point-of-no-return" - the non-linearity that is the crux of
> > > a decision - and how the relative timing of activity in distinct basal
> > > ganglia pathways can determine whether actions are released or cancelled.
> > >
> > >
> > >
> >

--

> > > abstract are below. If you would like to join in on informal conversations
> > > with Josh the afternoon before and/or the morning after his talk, please
> > > let me know.
> > >
> > > This event will be in the McGovern Seminar Room 46-3189, 6:00PM April 16
> > >
> > > Seeya there!
> > >
> > > Best
> > > Nancy
> > > ---------------
> > > No Going Back Now: Basal Ganglia Dynamics in the Selection and Suppression of Actions.
> > >
> > > Even when sensory cues are clear, the time taken to initiate a response is
> > > highly variable. Much of this variability reflects the dynamically varying
> > > state of cortical-basal ganglia networks at the time of sensory input,
> > > including dopaminergic modulation of striatal microcircuitry. I will
> > > discuss some recent results from ongoing studies of basal ganglia function
> > > during decision-making, using electrophysiological and voltammetric
> > > methods. Some areas of particular current interest are how the striatum
> > > approaches a "point-of-no-return" - the non-linearity that is the crux of
> > > a decision - and how the relative timing of activity in distinct basal
> > > ganglia pathways can determine whether actions are released or cancelled.
> > >
> > >
> > >
> >

--

subject: BME Seminar Series-Brad Aimone, Ph.D. April 10, 2013
bodyText:
BME Seminar Series
April 10, 2013
ERB 203 at 4:00

James Bradley Aimone, Ph.D.
Sandia National Laboratories

Title:
Adult Hippocampal Neurogenesis: Memory Resolution, Pattern Separation, or Both?

Abstract:
Over the past decade, adult neurogenesis in the dentate gyrus has received considerable attention due to its possible role in memory formation.  A growing debate in the neurogenesis community is whether new neurons simply enable the DG's pattern separation role or whether they contribute some other unique function that had not previously been considered by the hippocampal field.  My talk will describe a biologically realistic computational model that has been designed to test the potential role of new neurons in both pattern separation and "memory resolution" - an alternative framework for viewing the DG's function.  Further, I will describe how scaling the model to biologically realistic sizes is informative about what the value of new neurons are in human cognition.  Finally, I will show some new work on the impact of local network oscillations on new neurons and describe the potential role of this interaction on neurogenesis function.




--
Xue Han, Ph.D.
Assistant Professor, Biomedical Engineering Department
Joint Professor, Dept. of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics
Member, Photonics Center
Boston University
Room 521, 44 Cummington St., Boston, MA 02215
Phone: 617-358-6189<tel:617-358-6189>
Email: xuehan@bu.edu<mailto:xuehan@bu.edu>
Web: http://www.bu.edu/hanlab



--
Lara Maria Rangel

subject: FW: CompNet's Frank Guenther at Coolidge Corner Theatre
bodyText:
From: Cheryl White [mailto:cheryl@coolidge.org]
Sent: Friday, April 05, 2013 5:58 PM
To: Swenson, Sarah Mae
Subject: CompNet's Frank Guenther at Coolidge Corner Theatre

Dear Sarah,

I wanted to touch base to let you know that Frank Guenther will be the guest speaker at the Coolidge Corner Theatre's April 22nd Science on Screen program.  With Science on Screen, the Coolidge presents feature films and documentaries paired with science and technology experts.  This monthly series, now in its eighth season, is co-presented by The Museum of Science, Boston.


Professor Guenther will be speaking about brain-machine interfaces for locked-in patients before a screening of Julian Schnabel's 2007 film The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.  A synopsis of the program appears below. I'm hoping you will spread the word to the CompNet community.



Please let me know if you have any questions.  I would be happy to email you a PDF of our program flyer for posting.



We're looking forward to a compelling evening.  I hope you can join us.



Many thanks.



Best,



Cheryl White

Program Manager, Science on Screen

Coolidge Corner Theatre

cheryl@coolidge.org<mailto:cheryl@coolidge.org>

617/699-7285



______________________


Science on Screen Presents:
The Diving Bell and the Butterfly with cognitive and computational neuroscientist Frank Guenther
April 22 at 7:00 pm
Coolidge Corner Theatre, 290 Harvard Street, Brookline

In 1995, at age 43, Jean-Dominique Bauby, the successful and charismatic editor of Elle France magazine, suffered a massive stroke that left him with a rare condition called locked-in syndrome - mentally alert but unable to speak or move except for his left eye.  With the help of a speech therapist, he learned to communicate by blinking that eye to signify letters of the alphabet. Blink by blink, letter by letter, he dictated a memoir, which became an international bestseller and the basis for artist and director Julian Schnabel's fiercely beautiful film.  Working with the brilliant cinematographer Janusz Kaminski (Lincoln, Saving Private Ryan), Schnabel immerses us in Bauby's interior world - his memories, reveries, fantasies, loves and lusts - transforming a story of physical entrapment and spiritual renewal into exhilarating images.

Join us before the film for a talk by Frank Guenther, a professor in the Departments of Speech, Language & Hearing Sciences and Biomedical Engineering at Boston University, where he also is Associate Director for the Graduate Program in Neuroscience.  Professor Guenther uses a combination of brain imaging and computational modeling to characterize the brain networks involved in speech, and develops brain-machine interfaces (BMIs) that can restore speech and other capabilities to patients with locked-in syndrome.  BMIs have produced astonishing laboratory demonstrations of locked-in patients controlling computers, speech synthesizers, and robotic arms using only their thoughts. Clinical trials are ongoing for several BMIs, promising a much more normal life for those with locked-in syndrome as these devices become widely available.

Part of the Coolidge Corner Theatre's ongoing Science on Screen series. Tickets are $10 general admission or $8 students and Museum of Science members.  Coolidge Corner Theatre members get free admission.  For more information and to purchase tickets online, visit www.coolidge.org/content/diving-bell-and-butterfly<http://www.coolidge.org/content/diving-bell-and-butterfly>.  Tickets are also available at the Coolidge box office.

Science on Screen Presents:

The Diving Bell and the Butterfly with cognitive and computational neuroscientist Frank Guenther

April 22 at 7:00 pm

Coolidge Corner Theatre, 290 Harvard Street, Brookline

 

In 1995, at age 43, Jean-Dominique Bauby, the successful and charismatic editor of Elle France magazine, suffered a massive stroke that left him with a rare condition called locked-in syndrome – mentally alert but unable to speak or move except for his left eye.  With the help of a speech therapist, he learned to communicate by blinking that eye to signify letters of the alphabet. Blink by blink, letter by letter, he dictated a memoir, which became an international bestseller and the basis for artist and director Julian Schnabel’s fiercely beautiful film.  Working with the brilliant cinematographer Janusz Kaminski (Lincoln, Saving Private Ryan), Schnabel immerses us in Bauby's interior world — his memories, reveries, fantasies, loves and lusts — transforming a story of physical entrapment and spiritual renewal into exhilarating images.

 

Join us before the film for a talk by Frank Guenther, a professor in the Departments of Speech, Language & Hearing Sciences and Biomedical Engineering at Boston University, where he also is Associate Director for the Graduate Program in Neuroscience.  Professor Guenther uses a combination of brain imaging and computational modeling to characterize the brain networks involved in speech, and develops brain-machine interfaces (BMIs) that can restore speech and other capabilities to patients with locked-in syndrome.  BMIs have produced astonishing laboratory demonstrations of locked-in patients controlling computers, speech synthesizers, and robotic arms using only their thoughts. Clinical trials are ongoing for several BMIs, promising a much more normal life for those with locked-in syndrome as these devices become widely available.

 

Part of the Coolidge Corner Theatre’s ongoing Science on Screen series. Tickets are $10 general admission or $8 students and Museum of Science members.  Coolidge Corner Theatre members get free admission.  For more information and to purchase tickets online, visit www.coolidge.org/content/diving-bell-and-butterfly.  Tickets are also available at the Coolidge box office.

subject: GPN Faculty Lecture-Prof. Jason Ritt- Wednesday, March 20, 2013; Hariri Institute
bodyText:
Hariri Institute announces Distinguished Lecture by Prof. Evimaria Terzi

Is this email not displaying correctly?
View it in your browser<http://us6.campaign-archive2.com/?u=e3ad8f42733d54531fb729327&id=637a1b13d2&e=ce36c15009>.



[Rafik B. Hariri Institute for Computing and Computational Science & Engineering]<http://www.us6.list-manage1.com/track/click?u=e3ad8f42733d54531fb729327&id=737952bfc5&e=ce36c15009>




Wednesdays @Hariri<http://www.us6.list-manage1.com/track/click?u=e3ad8f42733d54531fb729327&id=e0b21ac707&e=ce36c15009>
3:00 PM   Wednesday, March 20, 2013


Distinguished Lecture

Jason Ritt
Assistant Professor of Biomedical Engineering
Hariri Institute Junior Faculty Fellow

Pinky and the Brain: Action and Actuation in the Sense of Touch

Abstract


Stimulation neurotechnology encompasses an expanding range of applications, from deep brain stimulation to sensory prosthetics.  I will discuss our recent efforts in applying neurocontrol to understand and manipulate biological active touch.  By active, we mean that neural activity depends not only on feedforward stimuli, but also on rapid information-driven feedback to sensing behaviors.   The presence of this closed loop motivates sensory prosthetic designs as dynamical control devices, and not simple encoders of fixed neural activity patterns.  To investigate active sensing, we use real time neurofeedback to alter cortical activity in freely exploring mice, a key model system for the study of touch.   Mice explore objects of interest through rhythmic 5-20 Hz whisker motions, with rapidly changing whisking in response to object contacts.  We express the light sensitive ion channel Channelrhodopsin-2 (ChR2) in populations of neurons in primary somatosensory cortex (SI), allowing optogenetic stimulation.  Using custom chronic implants, we perform multi-electrode cortical recording and optogenetic stimulation in SI, with bilateral facial electromyograms (EMG) and high speed video to track volitional whisker movement.  Expanding on previous reports in head-fixed mice with randomly timed SI activation, we find that locking stimulation to volitional motions can strengthen and regularize whisking, loosely consistent with palpations of virtual objects.  I will discuss our ongoing efforts to embed the stimulation paradigm into psychophysical tasks and neurocontrol theory.  Of particular interest to computational scientists are theoretical challenges to finding neurocontrol strategies appropriate to the "underactuated" context of current stimulation technology.  These initial results are a step toward developing control systems for use in studies of neural coding during active sensing, and potential sensory prosthetic devices.


Professor Jason Ritt joined the Department of Biomedical Engineering in 2010. His current research concentrates on how organisms gather and use information from their environment, through active sensing and sensory decision-making. For example, Prof. Ritt and his students are studying the ways in which mice explore environments using their whiskers, employing a combination of computational analysis of high-speed video, electrophysiological recordings, and neurocontrol methods implemented by a real-time feedback system built on a digital signal processing architecture. He received his Ph.D. in neuroscience and a Masters in mathematics from Boston University.

Lecture at 3:00 PM
Refreshments immediately following
Hariri Institute
111 Cummington Mall, MCS-180

subject: TOMORROW: Friday, November 18: Michael Häusser, Science of Learning seminar
bodyText:
CELEST Science of Learning Seminar

 

Dendritic computation

 


Michael Häusser, University College London   


The computational power of dendrites has long been predicted using modelling
approaches, but actual experimental examples of how dendrites solve
computational problems are rare. I will describe results from experiments
combining patch-clamp recordings with two photon imaging and glutamate
uncaging that demonstrate how single dendrites in the mammalian brain can
act as fundamental units of information processing. 
  

Friday, November 18, 2011 at 2:00PM

 

Boston University

677 Beacon Street

Auditorium, Room B02

Boston, MA 02215

Refreshments to follow in Room B03

 

 

For more information about this and other upcoming events please visit
http://celest.bu.edu <http://celest.bu.edu/>
