subject: TALK: 3pm Thurs., Nov. 17, Slow Learning and Invariance
bodyText:
Brains & Machines Seminar Series 2011-2012

Title: Slow Learning and Invariance
Speaker: Andreas Maurer
Date: 11-17-2011
Time: 3:00 PM - 4:00 PM
Location: Star Sem. Rm D463, Stata

Abstract:  The meaning of images observed in a natural sequence appears to
evolve slowly, with comparatively few sudden changes.
This principle of semantic continuity or slowness has been thought to play an
important role in the formation of the mammalian visual cortex, and several
machine learning algorithms have been proposed to exploit it for the learning
of feature maps invariant under certain geometric transformations, such as
translation, rotation or rescaling.
The talk focuses on the relationship between the nature of the observed
process and the class of semantic categories or invariances which can be
learned from its observation using the slowness principle. Some simulations
pertaining to the learning of scale invariance will also be presented.

The Brains & Machines Seminar Series 2011-2012 is being organized by the
IIT@MIT lab (a joint lab between MIT and the Italian Institute of Technology.)

Relevant URL(S): http://cbcl.mit.edu
_______________________________________________
Bcs-talks mailing list
Bcs-talks@mit.edu
http://mailman.mit.edu/mailman/listinfo/bcs-talks

P.S:  The complete abstract file can be viewed here:  Florian's
abstract<https://docs.google.com/open?id=17BSIZAkTolp-3yKDAB1wnjQ9RaDTrpIhgasRWyS4TeUla-Kv4qNGdKmEOn6n>

===============================================================================

Fitting psychometric functions contains several challenges. One challenge
is the decision which parameters of the function should be optimized versus
kept constant during optimization. Another is the sampling of the
psychometric function that influences the optimization and the goodness of
fit (Wichmann & Hill, Perception & Psychophysics 63(8), 2001). Thus, it is
advised in the experiment design to account for proper sampling and make
fewer assumptions by keeping parameters variable during the optimization.

I will present a maximum likelihood method (Treutwein & Strasburger,
Perception & Psychophysics 61(1), 1999; Myung, Journal of Mathematical
Psychology 47, 2003) estimating the parameters of psychometric functions
given sampled data. Furthermore, I’ll elaborate on the topic of goodness of
fit showing examples and giving interpretations.

bodyText:
Dear Colleagues,
Paul Garrity from Brandeis University will be here this Friday to give the MCN Seminar in Bldg. 46, Room 3002 from 4-5 PM. Paul is doing exciting work on the molecular basis of temperature detection and the role TRP channels play in this process. Troy

subject: [CNSO] Fwd: Nancy Kanwisher, next Friday!
bodyText:
FYI.
---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: "Carolyn Suchy-Dicey" <organizers@neuphi.com>
Date: Oct 18, 2011 6:15 PM
Subject: Nancy Kanwisher, next Friday!
To:

Dear Neuphi-ites:

Next *Friday, October 28th*, from *4 to 6 p.m.* *Nancy Kanwisher* of MIT
will be speaking about her work with fMRI, the title and abstract for which
are below (the paper is attached):

*Functional Specialization in the Human Brain: Evidence from fMRI*

*To what extent is the human brain composed of functionally specialized
components, each optimized to solve a single mental task?  My lab has used
fMRI to identify three regions that are very specifically engaged in the
recognition of faces, places and bodies. The very existence of these
regions--in more or less the same place in every normal subject--raises a
host of new questions that I will address here. Are specialized regions
found only for evolutionarily old functions? Are they found only for
perceptual and motor systems, or also for abstract higher-level thought? Can
we develop new methods that can discover such specializations even for
functions that we do not hypothesize in advance? How do specialized regions
arise in development? Why do some mental functions get their own private
patch of real estate in the brain and others (apparently) do not? In
addition to highly specialized regions, does the brain also have
general-purpose regions that are engaged across a wide range of tasks? We do
not yet have answers to all of these questions, but tantalizing clues are
turning up all the time.*

As with all Neuphi events, everyone is welcome to attend. The format
normally involves a one hour talk followed by one hour of discussion. The
website is http://www.neuphi.com for this and other events. As of now, the
location is set for Room 525 of 745 Commonwealth Avenue (STH), but keep your
eye(s) out for a room change in case I move it elsewhere.

I hope to see all of you soon!

Best wishes,

Carolyn Suchy-Dicey


-- 
Dr. Carolyn Suchy-Dicey
Psychology Department
Boston University
64 Cummington St.
Boston, MA 02215

Philosophy Department
Boston University
745 Commonwealth Ave.
Boston, MA 02215

subject: Cog Lunch at Noon
bodyText:
Come to Cog Lunch today for a stimulating talk and tasty food!

*Title*: Mechanisms of Peripheral Vision Explain Visual Search

*Abstract*: Vision is an active process: we repeatedly move our eyes to seek
out objects of interest and explore our environment.  Visual search
experiments capture aspects of this process, by having subjects look for a
target within a background of distractor objects. Search speed often
correlates with target-distractor discriminability; search is faster when
the target and distractors look quite different.  However, there are notable
exceptions. A given discriminability can yield efficient searches (where the
target seems to “pop-out”) as well as inefficient ones (where additional
distractors make search significantly slower and more difficult).  Search is
often more difficult when finding the target requires distinguishing a
particular configuration or conjunction of features.  Search asymmetries
abound.  These puzzling results have fueled three decades of theoretical and
experimental studies.  We argue that the key issue in search is not the
would-be appearance of items in the fovea, but rather the appearance of
image patches in the periphery, where appearance is characterized by summary
statistics computed over a sizable pooling region. By quantifying these
statistics, we predict a set of classical search results, as well as
peripheral discriminability of crowded patches such as those found in search
displays.  Additional modeling allows us to quantitatively predict mean
number of fixations to find the target.

Thanks,
Sam

_______________________________________________
Bcs-all mailing list
Bcs-all@mit.edu
http://mailman.mit.edu/mailman/listinfo/bcs-all

_______________________________________________
Bcs-visitors mailing list
Bcs-visitors@mit.edu
http://mailman.mit.edu/mailman/listinfo/bcs-visitors
bodyHtml:
Come to Cog Lunch today for a stimulating talk and tasty food!

Title: Mechanisms of Peripheral Vision Explain Visual Search

Abstract: Vision is an active process: we repeatedly move our eyes to seek out objects of interest and explore our environment.  Visual search experiments capture aspects of this process, by having subjects look for a target within a background of distractor objects. Search speed often correlates with target-distractor discriminability; search is faster when the target and distractors look quite different.  However, there are notable exceptions. A given discriminability can yield efficient searches (where the target seems to “pop-out”) as well as inefficient ones (where additional distractors make search significantly slower and more difficult).  Search is often more difficult when finding the target requires distinguishing a particular configuration or conjunction of features.  Search asymmetries abound.  These puzzling results have fueled three decades of theoretical and experimental studies.  We argue that the key issue in search is not the would-be appearance of items in the fovea, but rather the appearance of image patches in the periphery, where appearance is characterized by summary statistics computed over a sizable pooling region. By quantifying these statistics, we predict a set of classical search results, as well as peripheral discriminability of crowded patches such as those found in search displays.  Additional modeling allows us to quantitatively predict mean number of fixations to find the target.

Thanks,
Sam

subject: 10.19.11, 11.9.11 -- Autism and Developmental Disorders Colloquium Series at MIT
bodyText:
The Autism and Developmental Disorders Colloquium Series at MIT

"Commonalities among programs that have shown great promise in working with ASD
children"

Adele Diamond, Ph.D., FRSC
Canada Research Chair Tier 1 Professor of Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience,
University of British Columbia (UBC), Vancouver

6:00 p.m., Wednesday, October 19, 2011
MIT Building 46-3002 (auditorium), followed by a reception
Building Address:  43 Vassar Street, Cambridge, MA  02139

Hosted by John Gabrieli, Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, Harvard-MIT
Division of Health Sciences and Technology

Please RSVP to lmavros@mit.edu

Certain theater, juggling, and school curricular programs have achieved quite
impressive success with children with ASD.  They offer an alternative
perspective to behavioral modification approaches on how to help children with
ASD achieve their full potential and often find that that potential is far
greater than people had previously imagined.  That alternative perspective and
the evidence for it will be elucidated.


Supported by the Simons Initiative on Autism and the Brain at MIT
(web.mit.edu/autism)
________________________________________________________________________________
The Autism Consortium 2011 Symposium will take place on Tuesday, October 25,
2011 at the Joseph B. Martin Conference Center at Harvard Medical School.

Please register here: https://autismconsortium.eventbrite.com/

Registration opens at 8:30 AM.  From 8:30 - 9:30 AM there will be a Family
Resource and Research Fair with information booths featuring local autism
programs, as well as information on enrolling in the latest research studies.

The morning session begins at 9:30 AM with a welcome by Executive Director,
Deirdre Phillips.

A plenary session on New Visions for Autism Treatment will feature Christopher
McDougle, MD, Head of the Lurie Family Autism Center at Massachusetts General
Hospital; Jean Frazier, MD, Chair of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at the
University of Massachusetts Medical School and UMass Memorial Medical Center;
and William Barbaresi, MD, Associate Chief of the Division of Developmental
Medicine at Children's Hospital Boston.

A talk on Bridging Clinical Care and Clinical Research by Roula Choueiri, MD, a
Neurodevelopmental Pediatrician at the Floating Hospital for Children at Tufts
Medical Center will follow.

Next, Dennis Wall, PhD, Assistant Professor of Pathology and Director of the
Computational Biology Initiative at Harvard Medical School will present on his
work on Shortening the Behavioral Diagnosis of Autism Through Artificial
Intelligence and Mobile Health Technologies.

Lunch will offer a poster session highlighting research in progress.

The afternoon will begin with an important and timely session on Relaying
Research Findings to Families: Ethical and Legal Considerations by Pearl
O'Rourke, MD, Director, Human Research Affairs at Partners Health Care System.

Following this, Mark Daly, PhD, Associate Professor at the Massachusetts General
Hospital and Harvard Medical School, and an Associate Member of the Broad
Institute will provide an update on Autism Genetics:  New Advances and Future
Considerations.

Next Vijaya Ramesh, PhD, Associate Professor of Neurology (Genetics) at Harvard
Medical School and an Associate Neurologist at MGH will discuss her work on
Neuronal E3 Ubiquitin Ligase Pam in TSC/mTORC1 Signaling and Synapse
Development.

Several other talks are being planned and a reception for all will conclude the
day.

Register here: https://autismconsortium.eventbrite.com/

Check the website often for updates and the complete agenda at
www.autismconsortium.org and please share this invitation!

The Symposium will be held at The Joseph B. Martin Conference Center at Harvard
Medical School, 77 Avenue Louis Pasteur, Boston, MA 02115

For more information
email:  autismconsortium@hms.harvard.edu
call: 617-432-6961
________________________________________________________________________________
The Autism and Developmental Disorders Colloquium Series at MIT

"Genome-scale analyses of allele-specific expression and DNA methylation"

Andrew Chess, MD
Professor of Neuroscience
Professor of Developmental and Regenerative Biology
Professor of Genetics and Genomic Sciences
Mount Sinai School of Medicine

6:00 p.m., Wednesday, November 9, 2011
MIT Building 46-3002 (auditorium), followed by a reception
Building Address:  43 Vassar Street, Cambridge, MA  02139

Hosted by Li-Huei Tsai, Ph.D., Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences,
Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Please RSVP to lmavros@mit.edu

Common diseases clearly have a heritable component. The extent to which
epigenetic inheritance contributes to heritability, alongside of genetic
inheritance, remains to be determined.  I will discuss our genome-scale
approaches exploring DNA methylation polymorphism alongside of genetic
polymorphism.  Additionally, I will present our work on random monoallelic
expression of autosomal genes. Studying the human genome, and more recently the
mouse genome, we have discovered that random monoallelic expression, similar to
that observed in X-inactivation, is surprisingly common impacting around 10% of
autosomal genes.  We are currently exploring how this might impact
genotype-phenotype correlation by studying individual neurons in the brain.

Supported by the Simons Initiative on Autism and the Brain at MIT
(web.mit.edu/autism)
_______________________________________________

The Autism and Developmental Disorders Colloquium Series at MIT

"Genome-scale analyses of allele-specific expression and DNA methylation"

Andrew Chess, MD
Professor of Neuroscience
Professor of Developmental and Regenerative Biology
Professor of Genetics and Genomic Sciences
Mount Sinai School of Medicine

6:00 p.m., Wednesday, November 9, 2011
MIT Building 46-3002 (auditorium), followed by a reception
Building Address:  43 Vassar Street, Cambridge, MA  02139

Hosted by Li-Huei Tsai, Ph.D., Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences,
Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Please RSVP to lmavros@mit.edu

Common diseases clearly have a heritable component. The extent to which
epigenetic inheritance contributes to heritability, alongside of genetic
inheritance, remains to be determined.  I will discuss our genome-scale
approaches exploring DNA methylation polymorphism alongside of genetic
polymorphism.  Additionally, I will present our work on random monoallelic
expression of autosomal genes. Studying the human genome, and more recently the
mouse genome, we have discovered that random monoallelic expression, similar to
that observed in X-inactivation, is surprisingly common impacting around 10% of
autosomal genes.  We are currently exploring how this might impact
genotype-phenotype correlation by studying individual neurons in the brain.

Supported by the Simons Initiative on Autism and the Brain at MIT
(web.mit.edu/autism)

Subject: Please note seminar date correction:: Alexander Gramfort: Brain
    and Vision Resaerch Lab seminar-October 17th 12pm, ERB705

>
Subject: PLEASE POST: Alexander Gramfort: Brain and Vision Resaerch Lab seminar-October 18th 12pm, ERB705

Formal announcement will follow

Brain and Vision Research Seminar

Ill-posed problems in brain imaging: from MEG source estimation
to resting state networks and decoding with fMRI.

October 17, 12pm
Boston University, 44 Cummington str, ERB-705

Host: Lucia M. Vaina

If the number of parameters to estimate exceeds the number
of measurements, an estimation problem is said to be ill-posed.
Due to limited acquisition times, physics of the problems
and complexity of the brain, the field of brain imaging
needs to address many ill-posed problems. Among such problems
are: the localization in space and time of active brain regions
with MEG and EEG, the estimation of functional networks from fMRI
resting state data and what was is commonly called "decoding".
Decoding consists in predicting from fMRI data a behavorial
variable or classifying brain states using supervised learning
methods like SVM. In this talk I will describe some recent
contributions to all three problems. The concepts shared
by the different methods presented are:
estimation and statistical learning in high dimension,
convex optimization, sparse and structured priors.


Short bio
---------

Alexandre Gramfort is currently a research fellow at the Martinos Center for
Biomedical Imaging in Boston working with Matti Hamalainen. He was previously
postdoctoral fellow in the INRIA Parietal Project Team in Paris, France. He
obtained his PhD in 2009 from Telecom ParisTech under the supervision of
Maureen Clerc and Olivier Faugeras. He did his PhD jointly at INRIA in Sophia
Antipolis and the Computer Science Department at the Ecole normale supérieure
in Paris. He graduated from the Ecole Polytechnique in 2006 after a double
masters degree at Telecom ParisTech and the Ecole normale supérieure in Cachan
(DEA MVA). His research interests are on brain functional imaging (MEG, EEG,
fMRI) and in particular on problems involving signal and image processing,
scientific computing, numerical methods, data mining and machine learning.
Alexandre Gramfort received an award for his PhD work from the EADS foundation,
and awards at the Biomag conference in 2010 and HBM conference in 2011 for his
work on the MEG inverse problem.

Some references
---------------

Functional Brain Imaging with M/EEG Using Structured Sparsity in Time-Frequency Dictionaries
http://www.springerlink.com/content/mp7701m142193w83/

Brain covariance selection: better individual functional connectivity models using population prior
http://books.nips.cc/papers/files/nips23/NIPS2010_1054.pdf

Multi-subject Dictionary Learning to Segment an Atlas of Brain Spontaneous Activity
http://www.springerlink.com/content/c60kgvj402738763/

Total variation regularization for fMRI-based prediction of behavior.
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21317080?dopt=Abstract

Multi-scale Mining of fMRI data with Hierarchical Structured Sparsity
http://fr.arxiv.org/abs/1105.0363


______________________________
Lucia M. Vaina, M.D. Ph.D.
Professor

Brain and Vision Research Laboratory
Departments of Biomedical Engineering, Neuroscience and Neurology
Boston University, BME

44 Cummington St, Boston, MA 02215, USA
Tel: 617-353-2455; Fax: 617-353-6766; Email: vaina@bu.edu<mailto:vaina@bu.edu>

Lab website: http://www.bu.edu/bravi

subject: TODAY: SPECIAL TALK Profs. David Hubel & Torsten Wiesel's at MIT
bodyText:
Dear All,



Professor David Hubel and Professor Torsten Wiesel together will be giving a special talk discussing 'Early explorations of the visual cortex', which will be followed by a discussion with Professor Mark Bear on contemporary issues of visual cortex plasticity and visual information processing. The event will take place at 5 p.m. on Friday, October 14th in the Singleton Auditorium (MIT Bldg 46-3002). This will be followed by a wine-cheese reception in the atrium.

subject: Today! MIT COLLOQUIUM ON BRAIN AND COGNITON: Dr. Rita Balice-Gordon of University of Pennsylvania, Room 46-3002 at 4 pm
bodyText:
MIT COLLOQUIUM ON BRAIN AND COGNITION

Thursday, October 13, 2011, at 4:00 pm, MIT Building 46, Room 3002

*Speaker*: Dr. Rita Balice-Gordon of University of Pennsylvania
*Title*: Mechanisms of Autoimmune
Synaptopathies<http://picower.mit.edu/mechanisms-autoimmune-synaptopathies>
*Abstract*: Dr. Balice-Gordon's talk will focus on a cohort of recently
discovered human autoimmune disorders of memory, learning, cognition, and
psychosis in which the function of NMDARs, AMPARs and other synaptic and
cell surface proteins is directly affected by patient?s antibodies. These
disorders are naturally occurring models of human neuropsychiatric
dysfunction that are unique: they are relatively frequent; cause severe
memory loss; can be lethal but are potentially treatable; often affect
children; and frequently result in the transient misdiagnosis of children
and adults on the autism-schizophrenia spectrum. She will discuss recent
published work and unpublished results that establish the cellular and
synaptic mechanisms underlying these novel autoimmune synaptopathies and
mechanisms of recovery, provide insights into cellular and circuit
dysfunction caused by patients? antibodies, and begin to connect synaptic
and circuit dysfunction with the behavioral abnormalities that are hallmarks
of these disorders.

[image: Screen shot 2011-10-10 at 5.32.21 PM.png]

_______________________________________________
Bcs-talks mailing list
Bcs-talks@mit.edu
http://mailman.mit.edu/mailman/listinfo/bcs-talks

These disorders are naturally occurring models of human neuropsychiatric dysfunction that are unique: they are relatively frequent; cause severe memory loss; can be lethal but are potentially treatable; often affect children; and frequently result in the transient misdiagnosis of children and adults on the autism-schizophrenia spectrum. She will discuss recent published work and unpublished results that establish the cellular and synaptic mechanisms underlying these novel autoimmune synaptopathies and mechanisms of recovery, provide insights into cellular and circuit dysfunction caused by patients? antibodies, and begin to connect synaptic and circuit dysfunction with the behavioral abnormalities that are hallmarks of these disorders.

subject: [speechlabbu] Fwd: FW: HRC seminar tomorrow: Cara Stepp
bodyText:
FYI

-----Original Message-----
From: Gerald Kidd [mailto:gkidd@bu.edu]
Sent: Thursday, October 06, 2011 3:49 PM
To: akwok@bu.edu
Subject: HRC seminar tomorrow: Cara Stepp

Hi Ada.

Would you please pass this announcement along to members of the department.
Thanks.

  -Gerald


~~PLEASE NOTE LOCATION CHANGE: SEMINAR WILL BE HELD IN 677 BEACON ST, ROOM
B02. The seminar will begin at the regularly scheduled time, 10:30 AM ~~~

Friday - October 7

Speaker: Dr. Cara Stepp, Boston University

Title: Relative Fundamental Frequency as an Acoustic Correlate of Laryngeal
Tension

Abstract: The human voice is vital to communication, and allows us to
interact with others to express our thoughts, desires, and emotions.
However, for the 3 - 9% of the U.S. population with a voice disorder,
communication is impaired, causing them to suffer both economically and
socially. Vocal hyperfunction is a common cause of and accompaniment to
voice disorders characterized by excessive laryngeal and paralaryngeal
tension. Vocal hyperfunction can respond to behavioral intervention, but
successful treatment is dependent upon proper assessment. Although vocal
hyperfunction accounts for 10 - 40 % of cases referred to multidisciplinary
voice clinics, current assessment is hampered by the lack of objective
measures for detecting its presence or severity.  Our recent findings
indicate promise for the use of the non-invasive acoustic measure of
relative fundamental frequency (RFF) as such a measure. RFF is the
normalized fundamental frequency of vocal cycles immediately before and
after voiceless consonant production. We have shown RFF to (i) discriminate
between individuals with and without voice disorders associated with vocal
hyperfunction, (ii) normalize after successful voice therapy toward values
seen in unimpaired speakers, and (iii) correlate with listener
auditory-perception of vocal effort. Our findings support future large-scale
clinical studies of this measure.


***Seminars start at 10:30AM in Room 203 at 44 Cummington St. and end by
noon.  The event calendar of the HRC talks could be found at
http://www.bu.edu/dbin/hrc/calendar/.

Come early for coffee and donuts and stay for lunch**








-- 
<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>
Frank Guenther
Professor, Departments of Speech, Language, & Hearing
   Sciences and Biomedical Engineering
Associate Director, Graduate Program for Neuroscience
Boston University
677 Beacon Street
Boston, MA 02215
Phone: 617-353-5765   Fax: 617-353-7755
guenther@bu.edu
http://www.cns.bu.edu/~guenther

subject: Fwd: TOMORROW: Computation Lecture with Jeff Lieberman, 12:30pm @7-431
bodyText:
Please join us at this talk in the Computation Group Lecture Series, Department of Architecture, MIT:


“It's Not What You Think: An Evolutionary Theory of Spiritual Enlightenment”


October 7, 2011
12:30 - 2:00pm
Room 7-431(Long Lounge)


Jeff Lieberman
Artist and Scientist, Founder, Plebian Design

Abstract:
Take a broad perspective: Evolutionary theory provides us with an unpredictably deep connection
with the cosmos — a 13 billion year-old family tree. Your grandfather 300 million years ago was a
lizard. How did it experience life? Imagine the conscious experience of a reptile. Elements like
vision are similar, but higher functions are absent. Reptile consciousness is, in some way, a
definitively 'smaller' version of consciousness than what we have today. As evolution has changed
the structure of organisms, so has it changed the subjective experience. Don't forget, before any life
existed, you were once rocks, air, and water, with a dash of lightning.
This particular pattern of molecules known as a 'human being' has evolved an amazing depth of
consciousness: an ability to internally model the reality beyond the senses, to imagine futures that
have never happened, to use language, to use rationality to build and test theories about our
universe, to become self-aware. We often assume, due to these extreme capabilities, that the
average adult consciousness in 2011 is the apex of the evolution of consciousness, and that it is now
up to technology to propel us forward. So we work on changing the outside world to suit our needs,
instead of changing ourselves and the way our minds function.
As consciousness evolves, we gain wider and deeper understandings of the universe and of
ourselves. Where might it be headed next and what insights might we find? I believe that we have
specific pointers in front of us about the next qualitative stages in our evolution, and where this has
led has been surprising. As our evolutionary shifts in consciousness define how we see the world in
which we live, there may be nothing more important.
Bio:
Jeff Lieberman explores the connections between the arts, sciences, education, passion, creativity,
and the potential future of human consciousness. He hosts ‘Time Warp’ on the Discovery Channel,
composes music in the duo gloobic, and shows technological sculptures around the world.
Lieberman finished four degrees at MIT (BS: Physics, Math, MS: Mech. Engineering, Media Arts
and Sciences)

We hope to see you all there - please arrive to the lecture on time.
For more information please contact: danielas@mit.edu<mailto:danielas@mit.edu> and/or d_rosen@mit.edu<mailto:d_rosen@mit.edu>


_______________________________________________
Bcs-all mailing list
Bcs-all@mit.edu
http://mailman.mit.edu/mailman/listinfo/bcs-all

_______________________________________________
Bcs-visitors mailing list
Bcs-visitors@mit.edu
http://mailman.mit.edu/mailman/listinfo/bcs-visitors

subject: TODAY BCS COLLOQUIUM SERIES: RUDIGER WEHNER 10/6 @ 4PM
bodyText:
MIT COLLOQUIUM ON
THE BRAIN AND COGNITION
Thursday, October 06, 2011 | 4:00 pm
MIT Building 46, Room 3002 (Singleton Auditorium)

[cid:image003.jpg@01CC81B0.F9DA1CF0]

ABSTRACT:
How does a 0.1-mg brain housed in a 10-mg insect solve complex navigational tasks, which we humans would be able to accomplish only by employing topographic maps, Inertial Navigation or GPS devices?  In trying to answer this question the talk will focus on the extraordinary navigational skills of Cataglyphis, a visually guided desert ant, which has become a model organism for the study of animal navigation.  In the Sahara desert these ants forage individually over distances of several ten thousand times their body lengths and safely return to their starting point.  What do the compass and the odometer look like that the ants use in integrating their paths?  Is the spatial information provided by path integration and, in addition, by special landmark-guidance routines finally integrated into a "cognitive map" of the animal's foraging terrain?  A multidisciplinary approach combining behavioral and neurophysiological studies with computer simulations and robotics implementations is used to tackle such questions.  The talk deals with the particular navigational routines employed by the insect navigator, and finally concludes that these domain-specific routines interact flexibly within a distributed system rather than feed their information into a coherent global representation of space. What then do we mean when we feel inclined to credit the lowly ant with cognitive capacities?




_______________________________________________
Bcs-all mailing list
Bcs-all@mit.edu
http://mailman.mit.edu/mailman/listinfo/bcs-all

MIT COLLOQUIUM ON

THE BRAIN AND COGNITION

Thursday, October 06, 2011 | 4:00 pm

MIT Building 46, Room 3002 (Singleton Auditorium)

 

 

ABSTRACT:

How does a 0.1-mg brain housed in a 10-mg insect solve complex navigational tasks, which we humans would be able to accomplish only by employing topographic maps, Inertial Navigation or GPS devices?  In trying to answer this question the talk will focus on the extraordinary navigational skills of Cataglyphis, a visually guided desert ant, which has become a model organism for the study of animal navigation.  In the Sahara desert these ants forage individually over distances of several ten thousand times their body lengths and safely return to their starting point.  What do the compass and the odometer look like that the ants use in integrating their paths?  Is the spatial information provided by path integration and, in addition, by special landmark-guidance routines finally integrated into a “cognitive map” of the animal’s foraging terrain?  A multidisciplinary approach combining behavioral and neurophysiological studies with computer simulations and robotics implementations is used to tackle such questions.  The talk deals with the particular navigational routines employed by the insect navigator, and finally concludes that these domain-specific routines interact flexibly within a distributed system rather than feed their information into a coherent global representation of space. What then do we mean when we feel inclined to credit the lowly ant with cognitive capacities?

subject: TONIGHT -- "Common SNPs, rare CNVs, and the expression network between?"
bodyText:
The Autism and Developmental Disorders Colloquium Series at MIT

"Common SNPs, rare CNVs, and the expression network between?"

Lauren A. Weiss, Ph.D.
Staglin Family/IMHRO Assistant Professor, University of California, San
Francisco

6:00 p.m., Wednesday, October 5, 2011
MIT Building 46-3002 (auditorium), followed by a reception
Building Address:  43 Vassar Street, Cambridge, MA  02139

Hosted by Mark Daly, Ph.D., Associate Professor of Medicine, Harvard Medical
School

Please RSVP to lmavros@mit.edu

Recent genetic studies in common, complex heritable disease like autism spectrum
disorders have met success in two arenas: geneticists like to divide differences
among individuals into 'common polymorphisms' and 'rare variants', and often
argue about which kind of variation will be more important in disease risk. 
Both kinds of results provide challenges to direct translation into
neurobiological understanding of autism, as they rarely reveal easily
interpretable protein-coding mutations.  Common polymorphism association
signals often fall in noncoding sequences or between genes, and rare variants
in autism have primarily been large deletions and duplications including many
brain-expressed genes.  I will describe an approach to 'pathway' definition
using gene expression data that can unite a number of autism-implicated common
polymorphisms and rare variants into a network with functional implications.

Supported by the Simons Initiative on Autism and the Brain at MIT
(web.mit.edu/autism)

subject: TALK:Wednesday 10-5-11 Recursive Deep Learning in Natural Language Processing and Computer Vision
bodyText:
Recursive Deep Learning in Natural Language Processing and Computer Vision
Speaker: Richard Socher
Speaker Affiliation: Stanford University

Date: 10-5-2011
Time: 4:00 PM - 5:00 PM
Location: G449 (Kiva)

Hierarchical and recursive structure is commonly found in
different modalities, including natural language sentences and
scene images.  I will present some of our recent work on three
recursive neural network architectures that learn meaning
representations for such hierarchical structure. These models
obtain state-of-the-art performance on several language and
vision tasks.

The meaning of phrases and sentences is determined by the
meanings of its words and the rules of compositionality. We
introduce a recursive neural network (RNN) for syntactic parsing
which can learn vector representations that capture both
syntactic and semantic information of phrases and sentences. For
instance, the phrases "declined to comment" and "would not
disclose" have similar representations.  Since our RNN does not
depend on specific assumptions for language, it can also be used
to find hierarchical structure in complex scene images. This
algorithm obtains state-of-the-art performance for semantic scene
segmentation on the Stanford Background and the MSRC datasets and
outperforms Gist descriptors for scene classification by 4%.

The ability to identify sentiments about personal experiences,
products, movies etc. is crucial to understand user generated
content in social networks, blogs or product reviews. The second
architecture I will talk about is based on semi-supervised
recursive autoencoders (RAE).  RAEs learn vector representations
for phrases sufficiently well as to outperform other traditional
supervised sentiment classification methods on several standard
datasets.  Lastly, I describe an alternative unsupervised RAE
model that can learn features which outperform previous
approaches for paraphrase detection on the Microsoft Research
Paraphrase corpus.

This talk presents joint work with Andrew Ng and Chris Manning.


Bio:

Richard Socher is a Computer Science PhD student at Stanford,
co-advised by Chris Manning and Andrew Ng.  Most recently, he won
the Yahoo! Key Scientific Challenges Program Award and the
Distinguished Application Paper Award at ICML, 2011 for his work
on recursive deep learning.

Relevant URL(S): http://www.socher.org/
For more information please contact: David Wingate, 617 324 2894, wingated@mit.edu

subject: [CNSO] Student Seminar: Rob Law, Thursday 4-5 pm + Refreshments
bodyText:
Folks,

It is my pleasure to announce the continuation of student seminar series,
featuring Rob Law this Thursday from 4-5pm, in CNS basement.  Refreshments
will be served.

Please feel free to pass it along to interested groups.  :)

~NaN

Below is Rob's abstract:

 Symmetry has played a surprisingly minor role in brain theory despite
being vital to most other modern sciences. This is in part because the
symmetries of the nervous system are somewhat subtle, with classical group
structures appearing less prevalently than a collection of local, groupoid
symmetries. The recent dynamical systems literature has offered a compelling
and intuitive case relating such structural symmetries to synchrony and
phase-locking in networks of coupled dynamical systems. Such an approach is
immediately relevant to network modelers who take a deterministic
perspective, but related methods have been applied to stochastic systems as
well.

   The detection of symmetries and inference of their dynamical consequences
establishes a rough outline of the relationship between a structure and its
function. This is a major goal in the biological sciences in general, and to
this end, I will present a "physicist's proof" of a theorem relating the
left eigenvectors of a network's adjacency matrix to allowed synchronies and
phase relationships.  As a corollary, we will find that the Perron-Frobenius
eigenvector of this matrix directly indicates a network's "most synchronous"
possible state.  We apply this method to reproduce a number of previous
computational results and to discover unknown symmetries in some arbitrary
networks. Regarding the proof as informal, though, properly formalizing
the statement remains a priority. The remainder of the talk will focus on
some approaches taken toward this goal, extensions to the method, and
speculation on the roles of synchrony and phase in the nervous system.

Below is Rob's abstract:

 Symmetry has played a surprisingly minor role in brain theory despite being vital to most other modern sciences. This is in part because the symmetries of the nervous system are somewhat subtle, with classical group structures appearing less prevalently than a collection of local, groupoid symmetries. The recent dynamical systems literature has offered a compelling and intuitive case relating such structural symmetries to synchrony and phase-locking in networks of coupled dynamical systems. Such an approach is immediately relevant to network modelers who take a deterministic perspective, but related methods have been applied to stochastic systems as well. 

   The detection of symmetries and inference of their dynamical consequences establishes a rough outline of the relationship between a structure and its function. This is a major goal in the biological sciences in general, and to this end, I will present a "physicist's proof" of a theorem relating the left eigenvectors of a network's adjacency matrix to allowed synchronies and phase relationships.  As a corollary, we will find that the Perron-Frobenius eigenvector of this matrix directly indicates a network's "most synchronous" possible state.  We apply this method to reproduce a number of previous computational results and to discover unknown symmetries in some arbitrary networks. Regarding the proof as informal, though, properly formalizing the statement remains a priority. The remainder of the talk will focus on some approaches taken toward this goal, extensions to the method, and speculation on the roles of synchrony and phase in the nervous system.

subject: TALK:Tuesday 10-4-11 Geometry/topology and statistical inference
bodyText:
Brains and Machines Seminar Series 2011/2012
Geometry/topology and statistical inference
Speaker: Sayan Mukherjee
Speaker Affiliation: Duke University
Host: Lorenzo Rosasco
Host Affiliation: Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia (IIT); CBCL, MIT

Date: 10-4-2011
Time: 2:30 PM - 3:30 PM
Location: Sem Rm G449 (Patil/ Kiva)

In this talk I will illustrate two examples where geometric/topological ideas
and statistical inference complement each other. In the first example,
computational geometry is a central tool used to address a classic problem in
statistics, inference of conditional dependence. In the second example, a
classic object in topology and geometry, a Whitney stratified space, is stated
as a mixture model and an algorithm for inference of mixture elements is
provided as well as finite sample bounds for the algorithm.

The first part of the talk develops a parameterization of hyper-graphs based
on the geometry of points in d-dimensions, the geometric tool here is the
abstract simplicial complex. Informative prior distributions on hyper-graphs
are induced through this parameterization by priors on point configurations
via spatial processes. The approach combines tools from computational geometry
and topology with spatial processes and offers greater control on the
distribution of graph features than Erdos-Renyi random graphs.

In the second part of the talk, I describe the problem of stratification
learning. Strata correspond to unions and intersections of arbitrary manifolds
of possibly different dimension. We consider a mixture distribution on the
strata and formulate the following learning problem: given n points sampled
iid from the mixture model which points belong to the same strata. I will
state a bound on the minimum number of sample points required to infer with
high probability which points belong to the same strata. I will show results
of this clustering procedure on real data. The clustering procedure uses tools
from computational topology, specifically persistence homology.

No knowledge of geometry and topology is assumed in the talk.


The Brains&  Machines Seminar Series 2011-2012 is being organized by the
IIT@MIT lab (a joint lab between MIT and the Italian Institute of Technology.)

Relevant URL(S): http://cbcl.mit.edu/

subject: TALK:Friday 9-30-11 Perception, Action and the Information Knot that Ties Them
bodyText:
Brains and Machines Seminar Series 2011/2012

Perception, Action and the Information Knot that Ties Them
Speaker: Stefano Soatto
Speaker Affiliation: UCLA
Host: Lorenzo Rosasco
Host Affiliation: Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia (IIT); CBCL, MIT

Date: 9-30-2011
Time: 3:00 PM - 4:00 PM
Location: McGovern Seminar Room, MIT 46-3189

Abstract: I will describe a notion of Information for the purpose of decision
and control tasks, rooted in ideas of J. J. Gibson, and is specific to classes
of tasks and nuisance factors affecting the data formation process. When such
nuisances involve scaling and occlusion phenomena, as in most imaging
modalities, the "Information Gap" between the maximal invariants and the
minimal sufficient statistics can only be closed by exercising control on the
sensing process. Thus, sensing, control and information are inextricably tied.
This has consequences in understanding the so-called "signal-to-symbol
barrier" problem, as well as in the analysis and design of active sensing
systems. I will show applications in vision-based control, navigation, 3-D
reconstruction and rendering, as well as detection, localization, recognition
and categorization of objects and scenes in live video.

Speaker: Stefano Soatto is the founder and director of the UCLA Vision
Lab (vision.ucla.edu). He received his Ph.D. in Control and Dynamical
Systems from the California Institute of Technology in 1996; he joined
UCLA in 2000 after being Assistant and then Associate Professor of
Electrical and Biomedical Engineering at Washington University, Research
  Associate in Applied Sciences at Harvard University, and Assistant
Professor in Mathematics and Computer Science at the University of
Udine, Italy. He received his D.Ing. degree (highest honors) from the
University of Padova- Italy in 1992. Dr. Soatto is the recipient of the
David Marr Prize (with Y. Ma, J. Kosecka and S. Sastry) for work on
Euclidean reconstruction and reprojection up to subgroups. He also
received the Siemens Prize with the Outstanding Paper Award from the
IEEE Computer Society for his work on optimal structure from motion
(with R. Brockett). He received the National Science Foundation Career
Award and the Okawa Foundation Grant. He is a Member of the Editorial
Board of the International Journal of Computer Vision (IJCV), the
International Journal of Mathematical Imaging and Vision (JMIV) and
Foundations and Trends in Computer Graphics and Vision.

The Brains&  Machines Seminar Series 2011-2012 is being organized by the
IIT@MIT lab (a joint lab between MIT and the Italian Institute of Technology.)

Relevant URL(S): http://cbcl.mit.edu/

subject: Special Seminar Today at 1:30 PM in 46-3189
bodyText:
McGovern Institute Special Seminar

TITLE:  Automated whole-cell patch clamp electrophysiology of
neurons in vivo

SPEAKER:  Suhasa Kodandaramaiah
PhD student, Georgia Tech, and visiting PhD student, MIT
Laboratories of Craig Forest, Georgia Tech, and Ed Boyden, MIT

PLACE:  Room 46-3189

TIME:  Friday September 30, 2011, 1:30 PM

ABSTRACT:  Whole-cell patch clamp electrophysiology of neurons in vivo
enables the recording of electrical events in cells with great
precision, and supports a wide diversity of cellular morphological and
molecular analysis experiments.  However, high levels of skill are
required in order to perform in vivo patching, and the process is
time-consuming and painstaking.  An automated in vivo patching robot
would not only empower a great number of neuroscientists to perform
such experiments, but would also open up fundamentally new kinds of
experiment enabled by the resultant high throughput.  We discovered
that in vivo blind whole cell patch clamp electrophysiology could be
implemented as a straightforward algorithm, and developed an automated
robotic system capable of performing this algorithm.  We validated the
performance of our robot in both the cortex and hippocampus of
anesthetized mice.  Our robot achieves yields, cell recording
qualities, and operational speeds that are comparable to, or exceed,
those of experienced human investigators, and is simple and
inexpensive to implement.

bodyHtml:
McGovern Institute Special Seminar

TITLE:  Automated whole-cell patch clamp electrophysiology of  
neurons in vivo

SPEAKER:  Suhasa Kodandaramaiah
PhD student, Georgia Tech, and visiting PhD student, MIT
Laboratories of Craig Forest, Georgia Tech, and Ed Boyden, MIT

PLACE:  Room 46-3189

TIME:  Friday September 30, 2011, 1:30 PM

ABSTRACT:  Whole-cell patch clamp electrophysiology of neurons in vivo
enables the recording of electrical events in cells with great
precision, and supports a wide diversity of cellular morphological and
molecular analysis experiments.  However, high levels of skill are
required in order to perform in vivo patching, and the process is
time-consuming and painstaking.  An automated in vivo patching robot
would not only empower a great number of neuroscientists to perform
such experiments, but would also open up fundamentally new kinds of
experiment enabled by the resultant high throughput.  We discovered
that in vivo blind whole cell patch clamp electrophysiology could be
implemented as a straightforward algorithm, and developed an automated
robotic system capable of performing this algorithm.  We validated the
performance of our robot in both the cortex and hippocampus of
anesthetized mice.  Our robot achieves yields, cell recording
qualities, and operational speeds that are comparable to, or exceed,
those of experienced human investigators, and is simple and
inexpensive to implement.

bodyText:

From: Carol Y. Jefferson [mailto:caroly@bu.edu] 
Sent: Wednesday, September 21, 2011 10:48 AM
To: Carol Y. Jefferson
Cc: Magni, Nicole M
Subject: Fwd: October 7 - HRC Seminar

 


HRC Seminar Announcement:

Dr. Cara Stepp, Boston University
Friday, October 7, 2011,10:30 AM
677 Beacon Street, Rm. B02

For further information, please contact Nicole Magni (shutt@bu.edu).




From: "Magni, Nicole M" <nshutt@bu.edu>
Subject: October 7 - HRC Seminar

Dr. Cara Stepp, Boston University
 
Title:
"Relative Fundamental Frequency as an Acoustic Correlate of Laryngeal
Tension"
 
Abstract:
The human voice is vital to communication, and allows us to interact with
others to express our thoughts, desires, and emotions. However, for the 3 -
9% of the U.S. population with a voice disorder, communication is impaired,
causing them to suffer both economically and socially. Vocal hyperfunction
is a common cause of and accompaniment to voice disorders characterized by
excessive laryngeal and paralaryngeal tension. Vocal hyperfunction can
respond to behavioral intervention, but successful treatment is dependent
upon proper assessment. Although vocal hyperfunction accounts for 10 - 40 %
of cases referred to multidisciplinary voice clinics, current assessment is
hampered by the lack of objective measures for detecting its presence or
severity.  Our recent findings indicate promise for the use of the
non-invasive acoustic measure of relative fundamental frequency (RFF) as
such a measure. RFF is the normalized fundamental frequency of vocal cycles
immediately before and after voiceless consonant production. We have shown
RFF to (i) discriminate between individuals with and without voice disorders
associated with vocal hyperfunction, (ii) normalize after successful voice
therapy toward values seen in unimpaired speakers, and (iii) correlate with
listener auditory-perception of vocal effort. Our findings support future
large-scale clinical studies of this measure.
 
 
Nicole Magni
Center Administrator
Hearing Research Center
44 Cummington Street, Room 412
Boston, MA 02215

subject: FW: HRC Seminar TOMORROW - DR. FRANK GUENTHER
bodyText:
The talks will start at 10:30AM in room 203 at 44 Cummington St.
and go on to noon. The event calendar of the HRC talks could be found at http://www.bu.edu/dbin/hrc/calendar/.

Come early for the coffee and donuts!

=================================================

Friday, April 29, 2011
10:30AM-noon
Rm 203, 44 Cummington St.

Professor Frank Guenther
Department of Speech, Language and Hearing Sciences, Sargent College, Boston University

Title: The neural mechanisms of speech: From computational modeling to neural prosthesis

Abstract: Speech production is a highly complex sensorimotor task involving tightly coordinated processing in the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes of the cerebral cortex. To better understand these processes, our laboratory has designed, experimentally tested, and iteratively refined a neural network model whose components correspond to the brain regions involved in speech. Babbling and imitation phases are used to train neural mappings between phonological, articulatory, auditory, and somatosensory representations. After learning, the model can produce syllables and words it has learned by generating movements of an articulatory synthesizer. Because the model's components correspond to neural populations and are given precise anatomical locations, activity in the model's cells can be compared directly to neuroimaging data. Computer simulations of the model account for a wide range of experimental findings, including data on acquisition of speaking skills, articulatory !
 kinematics, and brain activity during speech. Furthermore, "damaged" versions of the model are being used to investigate several communication disorders, including stuttering, apraxia of speech, and spasmodic dysphonia. Finally, the model was used to guide development of a neural prosthesis aimed at restoring speech output to a profoundly paralyzed individual with an electrode permanently implanted in his speech motor cortex. The volunteer maintained a 70% hit rate after 5-10 practice attempts of each vowel in a vowel production task, supporting the feasibility of brain-machine interfaces with the potential to restore conversational speech abilities to the profoundly paralyzed.


FUTURE SEMINARS:

=================================================
Friday, May 6 - NO SEMINAR - ENG SENIOR PROJECTS!

10:30AM-noon
Rm 203, 44 Cummington St.

subject: [BROADCAST FROM SLHS] Research Seminar - Tuesday, May 3, 2011
bodyText:
From: Ada Kwok [mailto:akwok@bu.edu]
To: SAR faculty & staff
Subject: Research Seminar - Tuesday, May 3, 2011


***************************************************************************************************************

Hi everyone,

You are invited to attend the following research seminar:

Boston University Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
Research Colloquium Series


Jenny Thomson, Ph.D., CCC-SLP
Assistant Professor
Harvard Graduate School of Education


PRESENTS:  Is assistive technology really assistive?

"Written communication is evolving from a pen and paper activity to one frequently carried out using a computer, with the pace of change outstripping our ability to understand the effects upon individuals' ability to demonstrate knowledge. While there is evidence that the use of technology may help with lower level writing processes such as proofreading, grammar and spelling, early reports of the effects on higher level writing processes, required for success in higher education and the workplace, are mixed. This talk reports a study evaluating the impact of mode (pen versus keyboard) upon higher level writing performance for students with and without learning disabilities. The results provide insights into the strengths and limitations of current technologies in facilitating acquisition and demonstration of knowledge, as well as how this may vary among different populations of learners. "


DATE:  Tuesday, May 3, 2011

TIME:  12:00-1:00 pm

LOCATION:  SARGENT Rm. 220

Refreshments will be served.

Best wishes,
Ada



Ada Kwok
Assistant to the Chairman
Department of Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
Boston University Sargent College
635 Commonwealth Ave.
Boston, MA  02215
Phone:  617/353-3252
Fax:  617/353-5074

subject: [CRC] Wed 5/4 at noon, Brainmap talk by Riitta Hari (title and abstract)
bodyText:
Hi all,

More information about Riitta Hari's talk is included below.

- Matti

---------------

MGH / Martinos Center (Charlestown Navy Yard, building 149, room 2204
May 4 at noon

Time scales of human brain function: Insights from behavioral measures and neuromagnetic recordings
 
Riitta Hari
Brain Research Unit
Aalto University School of Science
Finland
hari@neuro.hut.fi
 
Human percepts, cognition, and actions are coordinated in a temporally accurate manner, with the relevant timescales ranging from milliseconds to several seconds. Multiple time scales typically govern the same behavior. During social interaction, such as free conversation, the speaker's articulation movements and other expressions change at time scales from tens to hundreds of milliseconds, and the prediction of and the reaction to the other speaker's talking can vary rapidly.  — I will discuss the role of magnetoencephalography (MEG), both evoked responses and the reactivity of brain rhythms, in assessing the dynamics of the rapidly changing human percepts and actions. My dream would be to move towards “2-person neuroscience”, to study—in not too distant future—the brain basis of social interaction in real time.
 
References:
Hari R and Kujala MV: Brain basis of human social interaction. From concepts to brain imaging. Physiol Reviews 2009, 89: 453–479.
Hari R, Parkkonen L and Nangini C: The brain in time: Insights from neuromagnetic recordings. The Year in Cognitive Neuroscience 2010, Ann NY Acad Sci 2010, 1191: 89–109.





---------

Matti Hamalainen, Ph.D.
Athinoula A. Martinos Center for Biomedical Imaging
Massachusetts General Hospital

msh@nmr.mgh.harvard.edu

subject: Fwd: MIT Neurotechnology Seminar - Eric Leuthardt - TODAY!
bodyText:
Don't know if you got this, but you might be interested--ECoG BCI, with some
speech decoding apparently...

----- Forwarded message from kerenm@MIT.EDU -----
    Date: Thu, 21 Apr 2011 09:32:57 -0400
    From: Keren Miller <kerenm@MIT.EDU>
Reply-To: Keren Miller <kerenm@MIT.EDU>
 Subject: MIT Neurotechnology Seminar - Eric Leuthardt - TODAY!
      To: "bcs-all@mit.edu" <bcs-all@mit.edu>, "mcgoverninstitute@mit.edu"
<mcgoverninstitute@mit.edu>, "pclm-all@mit.edu" <pclm-all@mit.edu>

MIT Neurotechnology Seminar

WHO:  Eric Leuthardt, MD
Washington University in St. Louis
Department of Neurosurgery, School of Medicine

TALK TITLE:   The Emerging World of ECoG Neuroprosthetics

WHEN:  Thursday 4/21, 1-2PM

WHERE:  Room 46-3002, MIT, Brain and Cognitive Sciences Complex (43
Vassar St., Cambridge, MA)

A Brain Computer Interface, (BCI), is a machine which can take some
type of signal from the brain and convert that information into overt
device control such that it reflects the intentions of the user¹s
brain.  In essence, these constructs can decode and use the
electrophysiological signals representing cognitive intent.  With the
parallel evolution of neuroscience, engineering, and rapid computing,
the era of clinical neuroprosthetics is approaching as a practical
reality for people with severe motor impairment. Patients with such
diseases as spinal cord injury, stroke, limb loss, and neuromuscular
disorders, may benefit through the utilization of these BCIs that
serve to augment their ability to communicate and interact with their
environment.   This talk will focus on the emerging use of
electrocorticography (ECoG), local field potentials taken from the
surface of the brain,  as a robust signal platform for neuroprosthetic
application.  Emerging insights from this signal modality reveal that
substantial motor and speech information can be derived from local
field potentials by looking at the higher frequency oscillations,
known as gamma rhythms. The combination of high information content,
minimal level of invasiveness, and strong signal durability, make
ECoG-BCIs a likely candidate for real world neuroprosthetics in the
future.

Host:  Contact Ed Boyden at esb@media.mit.edu to schedule appointments.

Best,
Ed




--
Ed Boyden, Ph. D.
Benesse Career Development Professor
Leader, Synthetic Neurobiology Group
Associate Professor, MIT Media Lab
Joint Professor, MIT Dept. of Biological Engineering, MIT Dept. of
Brain and Cognitive Sciences
Investigator, MIT McGovern Institute
Associate Member, MIT Picower Institute
Room E15-473B, 20 Ames St., Cambridge, MA 02139

subject: Title and Abstract for Mounya Elhilali's seminar Friday morning
bodyText:
To the Binaural Gang:
Just below you can find Mounya Elhilali's title and abstract.  Her 
seminar is Friday 10:30 ... our usual time and place.  If you would like 
to meet with her on Friday, please let me know.  Her time here is very 
limited, so we may not be able to accomodate all who are interested.
-Steve

TITLE:
Speech analysis by brains and machines: Implications of coding 
strategies in auditory cortex

ABSTRACT
The auditory system is tasked with representing complex sounds such as 
speech in such a way that we can separate competing sources, recognize 
various acoustic classes, and, in general, process complex auditory 
scenes. However, the principles governing how the auditory system 
-particularly at the level of auditory cortex- maps useful information 
from the environment into stable perceptual experiences remain unclear. 
A general proposal is that the system is constrained by ecological 
priors to shape the structure of neural computation. In this talk, I 
will discuss how neural responses over time can capture the statistics 
of speech sounds and how they influence the characteristics of a 
computational model of auditory cortical spectro-temporal receptive 
fields (STRFs). By constraining the ensemble output to be coherent in 
time, the resulting model receptive fields shed light on connections 
between the seemingly contradictory principles of sustained firing and 
sparseness in auditory sensory representations. Moreover, these findings 
suggest coding strategies that could mediate robust neural 
representations of speech signals in presence of unknown distortions by 
capturing the most informative statistics of speech. This framework puts 
constraints on the mapping from sound to internal representation along 
spectral and temporal modulation features with most important 
phonological information.

Inspired by these results, I will further discuss the relevance of such 
spectro-temporal modulation constraints in the recognition of speech 
sounds by both humans and machines. This analysis contrasts the 
predictability of speech recognition by human listeners based on overlap 
between speech modulation profiles and noise. It also provides a natural 
scheme to impart cortical principles into automatic speech recognition 
(ASR) systems. I will discuss a simple analysis based on modulation 
constraints for automatic phoneme recognition that outperforms several 
state-of-the-art ASR systems in non-stationary noise backgrounds.

To the Binaural Gang:
Just below you can find Mounya Elhilali's title and abstract.  Her seminar is Friday 10:30 ... our usual time and place.  If you would like to meet with her on Friday, please let me know.  Her time here is very limited, so we may not be able to accomodate all who are interested.
-Steve

TITLE:
Speech analysis by brains and machines: Implications of coding strategies in auditory cortex

ABSTRACT
The auditory system is tasked with representing complex sounds such as speech in such a way that we can separate competing sources, recognize various acoustic classes, and, in general, process complex auditory scenes. However, the principles governing how the auditory system -particularly at the level of auditory cortex- maps useful information from the environment into stable perceptual experiences remain unclear. A general proposal is that the system is constrained by ecological priors to shape the structure of neural computation. In this talk, I will discuss how neural responses over time can capture the statistics of speech sounds and how they influence the characteristics of a computational model of auditory cortical spectro-temporal receptive fields (STRFs). By constraining the ensemble output to be coherent in time, the resulting model receptive fields shed light on connections between the seemingly contradictory principles of sustained firing and sparseness in auditory sensory representations. Moreover, these findings suggest coding strategies that could mediate robust neural representations of speech signals in presence of unknown distortions by capturing the most informative statistics of speech. This framework puts constraints on the mapping from sound to internal representation along spectral and temporal modulation features with most important phonological information.

Inspired by these results, I will further discuss the relevance of such spectro-temporal modulation constraints in the recognition of speech sounds by both humans and machines. This analysis contrasts the predictability of speech recognition by human listeners based on overlap between speech modulation profiles and noise. It also provides a natural scheme to impart cortical principles into automatic speech recognition (ASR) systems. I will discuss a simple analysis based on modulation constraints for automatic phoneme recognition that outperforms several state-of-the-art ASR systems in non-stationary noise backgrounds.

subject: Second Annual CTSI Translational Research Symposium, May 26, 2011
bodyText:
Boston University
Clinical and Translational Science Institute

 Second Annual Translational Research Symposium



Thursday, May 26, 2011, 8:00 AM-2:00 PM



Boston University School of Management, 595 Commonwealth Avenue, 4th Floor

Boston, MA 02115



Sponsored By:

The Boston University Clinical and Translational Science Institute (CTSI)

http://ctsi.bu.edu/

David Center, MD, Institute Director and Associate Provost for Translational Research



Activities will include

*          Poster session, with prizes

*            Short talks: translational research challenges and successes at Boston University

*          Cross-campus networking

*          Information on translational research resources at Boston University



Keynote Speaker



Robert S. Langer Jr., ScD

David H. Koch Institute Professor, Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Engineering and Health Care: From the Discovery of the First Angiogenesis Inhibitors to the Development of Controlled Drug Delivery Systems and the Foundation of Tissue Engineering

Click here to learn about Dr. Langer<http://web.mit.edu/langerlab/langer.html>



Agenda



7:45 Registration



8:00 Light Breakfast



8:30 Welcome

David Center, MD, Institute Director and Associate Provost for Translational Research

            Robert S. Langer Jr., ScD, David H. Koch Institute Professor, Massachusetts Institute of Technology

          Spectrum Anticancer Activity

Remco Spanjaard, PhD, Associate Professor and Director of Research, Otolaryngology

          Mothers of Young Children with Developmental Delay

Emily Feinberg, ScD, CPNP Assistant Professor, Department of Community Health Sciences and Division of General Pediatrics

          Biomarker

          Success Story

12:30 Lunch and Networking



1:45 Poster Awards



2:00 Adjournment



Awards
Monetary awards will be presented to exceptional scientific posters with a trainee as the first author.  The awards will be to the first ($2500), second ($1000) and third ($500) place winner of the competition.

The on-line registration with poster abstract submission deadline is May 6, 2011 at 5:00 PM. Online registration for attendees without poster abstract submission is May 11, 2011 at 5:00 PM.



Information and notification of acceptance for posters, and attendance confirmation will be sent on

May 13, 2011. Set-up time is 7:30 AM the morning of the event.



Please register to attend the Symposium even if you are not submitting an abstract for poster presentation. There is no fee but pre-registration is required. Register early as seating is limited. Breakfast and lunch will be provided and we will need a count for food as well as poster spaces.

bodyText:

Date: 2011/3/28
Subject: NaK meets this Wed, Mar 30, at 4:00 PM
To: Motoharu Yoshida <motoharu.yoshida@gmail.com>, Horacio Rotstein <

Emma Myers <emyers@cns.bu.edu>, Aliaa Barakat <barakat@math.bu.edu>, Oded

Law <NoSimpler@gmail.com>, Ike Agbanusi <agbanusi@math.bu.edu>, Vassilis
Cutsuridis <vcut@bu.edu>, Emily Stephen <emilyps14@gmail.com>, Oliver Layton
<owl@cns.bu.edu>, Hisham Al Hasan <alhasan@mit.edu>, Sujith Vijayan <
svijayan9@gmail.com>, "Stephanie R. Jones" <srjones@nmr.mgh.harvard.edu>,
Ava Mauro <avamauro@bu.edu>, Xue Han <xuehan@bu.edu>, Jim Heys <
jimheys@gmail.com>, Jie Li <Jie.Li@tufts.edu>, Joan Butler <
jbutler@math.bu.edu>, Sam Isaacson <isaacson@math.bu.edu>, Nicholas James <
nickmontgomeryjames@gmail.com>, "L. Rocio Gonzalez" <rgonz@bu.edu>, Steven
Epstein <epstein@bu.edu>, Helen Barbas <barbas@bu.edu>, Tony Gao <
tgao@bu.edu>, Justine Cormier <jcorms@gmail.com>, Christoph Börgers <
cborgers@tufts.edu>, Stan Goldin <stan_goldin@hms.harvard.edu>, Erik
Sherwood <wesher@bu.edu>, John Burke <jb@math.bu.edu>, Michelle McCarthy <
mmccart@bu.edu>, Nan Jia <pacificmyth@gmail.com>, Spring Liu <jiahui@bu.edu>,
Jonathan Cannon <theoceanistea@gmail.com>, Mark Kramer <mak@bu.edu>, Nancy
Kopell <nk@bu.edu>, Eric Denovellis <edenovellis@gmail.com>, Tilman
Kispersky <tilman@bu.edu>, Aaron Hoffman <ah@math.bu.edu>, "Nathan W.
Schultheiss" <nschult@bu.edu>, Jason Ritt <jritt@bu.edu>, "Natallia V.
Katenka" <nkatenka@bu.edu>, Dmitri Pervouchine <dp@bu.edu>



                      NaK GROUP ANNOUNCEMENT


TIME      Wednesday, March 30, 2011 at 4:00 PM
PLACE     CBD Common Room (MCS 241)

SPEAKER   NATHAN SCHULTHEISS (Hasselmo Lab)

TITLE     Role of ICAN in rate, spike time, and theta phase coding by
          persistent spiking neurons of the medial entorhinal cortex

ABSTRACT

Persistent spiking neurons of the medial entorhinal cortex (mEC) exhibit
bistability in that they are quiescent in the absence of synaptic or applied
currents, but can be switched to a stable spiking state by a brief, strong
depolarizing input. The spiking state is thought to be maintained by a
positive feedback loop between a nonspecific calcium-sensitive cationic
current (ICAN) carried by TRPC membrane channels and heightened
intracellular calcium levels sustained during sufficiently fast spiking.
Persistent spiking neurons in layer V of mEC are capable of sustaining a
continuous range of stable spiking frequencies and can be switched to higher
or lower frequencies by additional strong depolarizing or hyperpolarizing
pulses, respectively.  This ability to generate graded persistent spiking
has been hypothesized to underlie aspects of working memory, but it remains
unclear if and to what extent persistent spiking is robust to the
considerable fluctuating synaptic conductance that would be expected in
vivo.  Furthermore, the contribution of ICAN to the input-output processing
of these neurons has not been evaluated. In this study we use a
multi-compartmental GENESIS model of a layer V mEC neuron to investigate how
ICAN might contribute to rate, spike time, and theta phase coding in these
neurons.  In the absence of synaptic inputs, we vary either an applied
holding current or the magnitude of a 1 second current pulse delivered to
the base model or to a version of the model from which ICAN has been
removed.  We then evaluate the spike frequency to applied current
relationship at different time-points over the next 10 seconds. To explore
the potential role of ICAN in spike time coding we deliver a 500 pA, 1
second current pulse during ongoing stochastic backgrounds composed of 1 nS
AMPA and GABA synaptic events delivered to the soma. These backgrounds are
intended to represent the in vivo high-conductance state. We then evaluate
the spike-triggered average (STA) of the CAN current before and after the
pulse. We also derive the STAs of voltage (mean spike shape) and AMPA and
GABA input conductances to evaluate how activation of ICAN might affect
spike threshold and sensitivity to synaptic input fluctuations. Lastly, we
delivered theta modulated synaptic input to the model and evaluate the
preferred firing phase of the model for different levels of ICAN activation.
We find that: 1) ICAN shapes the spike frequency to current relationship in
a time-dependent manner; 2) The CAN current can support long-lasting
elevated firing rates following strong excitation amidst ongoing stochastic
synaptic activity; 3) Activation of the CAN current with a current pulse
increases sensitivity to future synaptic input fluctuations; 4) Increased
sensitivity is long-lasting and is greater for stronger pulses, allowing the
CAN current to act as an intrinsic gain control mechanism.



-- 
Nan Jia
Cognitive and Neural Systems
Boston University

Schultheiss" <nschult@bu.edu>, Jason Ritt <jritt@bu.edu>, "Natallia V. Katenka" <nkatenka@bu.edu>, Dmitri Pervouchine <dp@bu.edu>



                      NaK GROUP ANNOUNCEMENT


TIME      Wednesday, March 30, 2011 at 4:00 PM
PLACE     CBD Common Room (MCS 241)

SPEAKER   NATHAN SCHULTHEISS (Hasselmo Lab)

TITLE     Role of ICAN in rate, spike time, and theta phase coding by
          persistent spiking neurons of the medial entorhinal cortex

ABSTRACT

Persistent spiking neurons of the medial entorhinal cortex (mEC) exhibit bistability in that they are quiescent in the absence of synaptic or applied currents, but can be switched to a stable spiking state by a brief, strong depolarizing input. The spiking state is thought to be maintained by a positive feedback loop between a nonspecific calcium-sensitive cationic current (ICAN) carried by TRPC membrane channels and heightened intracellular calcium levels sustained during sufficiently fast spiking. In this study we use a multi‑compartmental GENESIS model of a layer V mEC neuron to investigate how ICAN might contribute to rate, spike time, and theta phase coding in these neurons.  In the absence of synaptic inputs, we vary either an applied holding current or the magnitude of a 1 second current pulse delivered to the base model or to a version of the model from which ICAN has been removed.  We then evaluate the spike frequency to applied current relationship at different time-points over the next 10 seconds. To explore the potential role of ICAN in spike time coding we deliver a 500 pA, 1 second current pulse during ongoing stochastic backgrounds composed of 1 nS AMPA and GABA synaptic events delivered to the soma. These backgrounds are intended to represent the in vivo high-conductance state. We then evaluate the spike-triggered average (STA) of the CAN current before and after the pulse. We also derive the STAs of voltage (mean spike shape) and AMPA and GABA input conductances to evaluate how activation of ICAN might affect spike threshold and sensitivity to synaptic input fluctuations. Lastly, we delivered theta modulated synaptic input to the model and evaluate the preferred firing phase of the model for different levels of ICAN activation. We find that: 1) ICAN shapes the spike frequency to current relationship in a time-dependent manner; 2) The CAN current can support long-lasting elevated firing rates following strong excitation amidst ongoing stochastic synaptic activity; 3) Activation of the CAN current with a current pulse increases sensitivity to future synaptic input fluctuations; 4) Increased sensitivity is long-lasting and is greater for stronger pulses, allowing the CAN current to act as an intrinsic gain control mechanism.



--
Nan Jia
Cognitive and Neural Systems
Boston University

subject: talk tomorrow
bodyText:
Dear students and colleagues--

Assoc. Provost Andrei Ruckenstein just asked me to draw your attention to the talk described below, to be on the MED campus tomorrow at 2 pm.

The speaker, Newton Howard, is an important figure; it would be very nice if tomorrow's turn out included good representation from students and colleagues from the Charles River Campus-- something that is not always the case for talks at MED.

Dr. Howard has a very interesting background:
> Dr. Newton Howard is the director of the Mind Machine Project and a research scientist at MIT. He received his Doctoral degree in Cognitive Informatics and Mathematics from the University of Paris 1 - La Sorbonne (France) where he was also awarded the Habilitation à Diriger des Recherches for his leading work on the Physics of Cognition (PoC) and its applications to complex medical, economic, and security problems. While a graduate at the  Faculty of Mathematical Sciences at the University of Oxford, England, he proposed the Theory of Intention Awareness (IA). He held positions as a professor of Mathematics and Psychiatry at The George Washington University, where he established leading academic programs directed to solve real world problems. 

I encourage those of you who are free make a real effort to attend.

Barb 

ANATOMY AND NEUROBIOLOGY DEPARTMENT SEMINAR
 
"Mind Machine Project: Emerging Conscious Systems"
 
by Newton Howard, Ph.D.
Director of the Mind Machine Project (MMP)
Massachusetts Institute of Technology
  
Thursday, March 24, 2011
2:00pm
Alan Peters Seminar Room
Instructional Building, L-1008

subject: Fwd: Lecture: Magnetoencephalography Imaging Technology
bodyText:
---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: McGovern Institute for Brain Research <jpryor@mit.edu>
Date: Wed, Mar 16, 2011 at 4:13 PM
Subject: Lecture: Magnetoencephalography Imaging Technology
To: bcs talks <bcs-talks@mit.edu>


  [image: McGovern Institute for Brain Research at MIT]    McGovern
Institute LectureMonday March 21, 2011 | 10:00 A. M. ET
Magnetoencephalography Imaging Technology  The McGovern Institute for
Brain Research has recently acquired a
magnetoencephalography (MEG) imaging system. MEG is a safe and noninvasive
technique for measuring neuronal activity in the human brain. Using magnetic
sensors surrounding the head, MEG records the weak magnetic fields generated
by active neurons. The new MEG scanner, an Electa Triux with 306 channels
plus 128 channels for EEG, is housed at the Martinos Imaging Center at MIT,
within a 3-layer shielded room with active compensation coils to reduce
magnetic background noise. The imaging facility is available to the entire
MIT community and to their external collaborators.

The following two-part lecture will introduce the new imaging technology.

*Title:* Magnetoencephalography Imaging Technology
Part 1: Introduction to MEG Imaging
Part 2: MEG Operational Procedures

*Speaker:* Ronald S. Gordon, Ph.D., Elekta Neuromag, Canada
*Time:* 10am-12pm
*Date:* Monday, 21 March 2011
*Location:* PILM Seminar Room, MIT 46-3310

*Abstract:* This 2-part lecture will introduce MEG imaging to the MIT
community. The first hour will provide an overview of MEG, including:
historical development, basic MEG physics, noise cancellation, basic source
modeling, and experimental and clinical applications. After a break, the
second hour will concentrate on operational details of the Elekta Triux MEG
System and is targeted to individuals who may be interested in using the
imaging facility.

   *Contact: Dimitrios Pantazis*
email: pantazis@MIT.EDU | tel: 617.715.4330   To unsubscribe from our
Institute News mailing list, please reply to this message with the text
UNSUBSCRIBE in the body of the email.

subject: Fwd: BCS Special Seminar: Faculty Candidate: tomorrow, Tuesday 3.15.111 at 10am; Josh H. McDermott, NYU, Understanding Audition Via Sound Analysis and Synthesis
bodyText:
---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Kathleen Veronica Dickey <kvdickey@mit.edu>
Date: Mon, Mar 14, 2011 at 10:38 AM
Subject: RE: BCS Special Seminar: Faculty Candidate: tomorrow, Tuesday
3.15.111 at 10am; Josh H. McDermott, NYU, Understanding Audition Via Sound
Analysis and Synthesis
To: "bcs-talks@mit.edu" <bcs-talks@mit.edu>


BCS Special Seminar: Faculty Candidate

Tomorrow

Speaker               Josh H. McDermott, Center for Neural Science, New York
University

Time                      10am

Date                      Tuesday, 15 March 2011

Place                     Singleton Auditorium, 46-3002

Title                       Understanding Audition Via Sound Analysis and
Synthesis

*Abstract: *Humans infer many important things about the world from the
sound pressure waveforms that enter the ears. In doing so we solve a number
of difficult and intriguing computational problems. We recognize sound
sources despite large variability in the waveforms they produce, extract
behaviorally relevant attributes that are not explicit in the input to the
ear, and do so even when sound sources are embedded in dense mixtures with
other sounds. This talk will describe my recent work investigating how we
accomplish these feats. The work stems from two premises: first, that
understanding perception requires understanding real-world sensory stimuli
and their representation in the brain, and second, that a theory of the
perception of some property should enable the synthesis of signals that
appear to have that property. Sound synthesis can thus be used to probe
phenomena inaccessible to conventional experimental methods. I will discuss
three related strands of research along these lines. The first strand uses
sound textures (as produced by rain, swarms of insects, or galloping horses)
as a window into the auditory system, synthesizing textures from statistics
of biological sound representations as tests of the perceptual relevance of
different acoustic measurements. The second strand uses naturalistic
synthetic sounds to reveal new aspects of sound segregation. The third
strand, currently in progress, capitalizes on the ease with which real-world
sound sources and their mixtures can be obtained, using large-scale
statistical analysis of sounds to empirically study the sound properties
that serve as grouping cues. Collectively they indicate that simple
statistical properties of auditory representations capture a surprising
number of important perceptual phenomena.





[image: MIT: Massachusetts Institute of Technology]

* *

Kathleen V. Dickey | Development Coordinator

*Dept. of Brain + Cognitive Sciences** *

46-2005 | 77 Massachusetts Avenue | Cambridge, MA  02139

617.324.5399 (o)   617.258.9216 (fax)  |  kvdickey@mit.edu

P *Think Green!   Before printing this e-mail ask yourself, do I really need
a hard copy?*







_______________________________________________
Bcs-talks mailing list
Bcs-talks@mit.edu
http://mailman.mit.edu/mailman/listinfo/bcs-talks
