From: Kathleen Veronica Dickey <kvdickey@mit.edu>

To: "bcs-talks@mit.edu" <bcs-talks@mit.edu>


BCS Special Seminar: Faculty Candidate

Tomorrow

Speaker               Josh H. McDermott, Center for Neural Science, New York University

Time                      10am

Date                      Tuesday, 15 March 2011

Place                     Singleton Auditorium, 46-3002

Title                       Understanding Audition Via Sound Analysis and Synthesis

Abstract: Humans infer many important things about the world from the sound pressure waveforms that enter the ears. In doing so we solve a number of difficult and intriguing computational problems. We recognize sound sources despite large variability in the waveforms they produce, extract behaviorally relevant attributes that are not explicit in the input to the ear, and do so even when sound sources are embedded in dense mixtures with other sounds. This talk will describe my recent work investigating how we accomplish these feats. The work stems from two premises: first, that understanding perception requires understanding real-world sensory stimuli and their representation in the brain, and second, that a theory of the perception of some property should enable the synthesis of signals that appear to have that property. Sound synthesis can thus be used to probe phenomena inaccessible to conventional experimental methods. I will discuss three related strands of research along these lines. The first strand uses sound textures (as produced by rain, swarms of insects, or galloping horses) as a window into the auditory system, synthesizing textures from statistics of biological sound representations as tests of the perceptual relevance of different acoustic measurements. The second strand uses naturalistic synthetic sounds to reveal new aspects of sound segregation. The third strand, currently in progress, capitalizes on the ease with which real-world sound sources and their mixtures can be obtained, using large-scale statistical analysis of sounds to empirically study the sound properties that serve as grouping cues. Collectively they indicate that simple statistical properties of auditory representations capture a surprising number of important perceptual phenomena.

subject: Fwd: Talk at MEEI on Friday March 11: Kiran on aphasia
bodyText:
---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Eatock, Ruth Anne <Ruth-Anne_Eatock@meei.harvard.edu>
Date: Mon, Mar 7, 2011 at 11:58 AM
Subject: Talk at MEEI on Friday March 11: Kiran on aphasia
To: SAP-Talks <SAP-Talks@meei.harvard.edu>


·         *Friday March 11 2011, 2 p.m.*

3rd Floor:  Sloane Rm, MEEI, 243 Charles Street Boston 02114
Swathi Kiran, Ph.D., *Boston University* Language recovery in individuals
with aphasia: Perspectives from neuroimaging and rehabilitation data



*Abstract:*  In the US, every year, approximately 80,000 individuals incur
aphasia each year. Naming deficits are the most persistent language deficits
observed in patients with aphasia. Currently, clinicians proceed from simple
items to complex items during therapy of naming deficits. Our previous work,
however, has demonstrated that training the more complex atypical examples
(e.g., *garlic*) of a category (e.g., *vegetable)* results in generalization
to the less complex typical examples (e.g., *carrots*) in aphasic patients
with naming deficits (Kiran, 2007). An important unresolved question is
whether behavioral improvements following the treatments described above are
due to some long lasting neural reorganization of restored function or due
to the development of alternative behavioral strategies (Ramage, Kiran &
Robin, 2007). Therefore, a natural progression of my research program now
involves the implementation of advanced imaging technology to carefully
examine the basis of language recovery subsequent to behavioral treatment in
individuals with aphasia. In this talk, I will present data from our
rehabilitation studies that provide the basis for assuming systematic and
effective recovery of language skills in monolingual and bilingual aphasia.
I will also present data from neuroimaging studies that examine the neural
basis of language recovery and language rehabilitation in aphasia. Our
recent evidence indicates that perilesional and undamaged regions in the
lesioned hemisphere are engaged in language recovery subsequent to
rehabilitation.


Full seminar schedule:
http://www.masseyeandear.org/research/ent/eaton-peabody/epl-seminar-schedules/
Directions:
http://www.masseyeandear.org/about-us/maps-directions/main-campus/
bodyHtml:
---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Eatock, Ruth Anne <Ruth-Anne_Eatock@meei.harvard.edu>
Date: Mon, Mar 7, 2011 at 11:58 AM
Subject: Talk at MEEI on Friday March 11: Kiran on aphasia
To: SAP-Talks <SAP-Talks@meei.harvard.edu>


·         Friday March 11 2011, 2 p.m.

3rd Floor:  Sloane Rm, MEEI, 243 Charles Street Boston 02114

Swathi Kiran, Ph.D., Boston University

Language recovery in individuals with aphasia: Perspectives from neuroimaging and rehabilitation data

 

Abstract:  In the US, every year, approximately 80,000 individuals incur aphasia each year. Naming deficits are the most persistent language deficits observed in patients with aphasia. Currently, clinicians proceed from simple items to complex items during therapy of naming deficits. Our previous work, however, has demonstrated that training the more complex atypical examples (e.g., garlic) of a category (e.g., vegetable) results in generalization to the less complex typical examples (e.g., carrots) in aphasic patients with naming deficits (Kiran, 2007). An important unresolved question is whether behavioral improvements following the treatments described above are due to some long lasting neural reorganization of restored function or due to the development of alternative behavioral strategies (Ramage, Kiran & Robin, 2007). Therefore, a natural progression of my research program now involves the implementation of advanced imaging technology to carefully examine the basis of language recovery subsequent to behavioral treatment in individuals with aphasia. In this talk, I will present data from our rehabilitation studies that provide the basis for assuming systematic and effective recovery of language skills in monolingual and bilingual aphasia. I will also present data from neuroimaging studies that examine the neural basis of language recovery and language rehabilitation in aphasia. Our recent evidence indicates that perilesional and undamaged regions in the lesioned hemisphere are engaged in language recovery subsequent to rehabilitation.

 

Full seminar schedule: http://www.masseyeandear.org/research/ent/eaton-peabody/epl-seminar-schedules/
Directions: http://www.masseyeandear.org/about-us/maps-directions/main-campus/

subject: [CRC] An event you might be interested in: April 14
bodyText:
Dear CRCers,

Various groups at Boston University are sponsoring a Mini-Symposium on
Brain Rhythms and Audition.  There will be 4 speakers:  Charles Schroeder,
Miles Whittington, Barb Shinn-Cunningham and Oded Ghitza.  It will be 1-5,
April 14, at the BU Hillel House.  (The reception after will feature
kosher food!)

This mini is being organized in connection with Miles' visit to BU to
speak to the Graduate program in Neuroscience.  That talk (entirely
different from the April 14 one) will be at noon on April 15.  More
details to come later.

Best
Nancy

subject: [CNSO]Fwd: NaK meets this **THU**, 3/3, at 4:00
bodyText:
NaK GROUP ANNOUNCEMENT


TIME      *THURSDAY*, MARCH 3, 2011, at 4:00 PM
PLACE     CBD Common Room (MCS 241)

SPEAKER   MARLENE COHEN  (Maunsell Lab, Harvard Med School)

TITLE     A common mechanism for processes that change neuronal gains

ABSTRACT

A variety of sensory, motor, and cognitive processes change the gains of
cortical neurons, and gain changes have been proposed to be a general
feature of cortical computation. One of the most well-studied of these
processes is spatial attention, which affects both perception and the gains
of visual neurons. We also found evidence that changes in spatial attention
are associated with changes in the extent to which trial-to-trial
variability in neuronal responses is shared across a population.  We tested
the hypothesis that a common mechanism mediates all processes that change
gains by training rhesus monkeys to perform a task in which we could
simultaneously manipulate spatial attention and a form of feature or task
attention. We compared the effects of feature and spatial attention on local
and spatially separated populations by recording simultaneously from dozens
of neurons in both hemispheres of V4. Feature and spatial attention affect
the activity of local populations similarly, modulating both firing rates
and correlations between pairs of nearby neurons. However, while spatial
attention appears to act on local populations, feature attention is
coordinated across hemispheres. Our results are consistent with a unified
attentional mechanism that can modulate the responses of arbitrary subgroups
of neurons.




-- 
Nan Jia
Cognitive and Neural Systems
Boston University
bodyHtml:
NaK GROUP ANNOUNCEMENT


TIME      *THURSDAY*, MARCH 3, 2011, at 4:00 PM
PLACE     CBD Common Room (MCS 241)

SPEAKER   MARLENE COHEN  (Maunsell Lab, Harvard Med School)

TITLE     A common mechanism for processes that change neuronal gains

ABSTRACT

A variety of sensory, motor, and cognitive processes change the gains of cortical neurons, and gain changes have been proposed to be a general feature of cortical computation. One of the most well-studied of these processes is spatial attention, which affects both perception and the gains of visual neurons. We also found evidence that changes in spatial attention are associated with changes in the extent to which trial-to-trial variability in neuronal responses is shared across a population.  We tested the hypothesis that a common mechanism mediates all processes that change gains by training rhesus monkeys to perform a task in which we could simultaneously manipulate spatial attention and a form of feature or task attention. We compared the effects of feature and spatial attention on local and spatially separated populations by recording simultaneously from dozens of neurons in both hemispheres of V4. Feature and spatial attention affect the activity of local populations similarly, modulating both firing rates and correlations between pairs of nearby neurons. However, while spatial attention appears to act on local populations, feature attention is coordinated across hemispheres. Our results are consistent with a unified attentional mechanism that can modulate the responses of arbitrary subgroups of neurons.




--
Nan Jia
Cognitive and Neural Systems
Boston University

subject: [BROADCAST FROM ADA KWOK] NEW LOCATION for March 1 Research Seminar
bodyText:
From: Ada Kwok [mailto:akwok@bu.edu]
To: SAR faculty & staff
Subject: NEW LOCATION for March 1 Research Seminar



***************************************************************************

Hi everyone,

The new location for the research seminar on Tuesday, March 1 at 12:00 is Sargent Rm. 220.

Boston University Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences Research Colloquium Series

Marina Bedny, Ph.D.
Postdoctoral Fellow
Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences
Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Presents: Effects of developmental experience on the neural basis of language

Abstract: "My research examines the origins and structure of language in the human brain. In this talk, I will discuss what blindness can tell us about the role of experience in shaping language. In general, the acquisition and neural basis of language are highly consistent across individuals, languages, and cultures, leading to the hypothesis that humans have evolved brain regions in left frontal and temporal cortex that are uniquely capable of language. By contrast, I will present evidence that in congenitally blind individuals, additional brain regions in occipital cortex (traditional visual regions) become involved in language processing. These occipital regions are involved in language processing in blind children as young as 4 years of age, and prior to the specialization of classic frontotemporal language regions. These findings have far reaching implications: (1) brain regions that evolved for vision can take on language functions as a result of early experience, and (2) innate biological properties are not necessary for a brain region to become involved in language (3) the typical neural basis of language develops through an experience-sensitive process of self-organization."

Refreshments will be served.


Best wishes,
Ada





Ada Kwok
Assistant to the Chairman
Department of Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences
Boston University Sargent College
635 Commonwealth Ave.
Boston, MA  02215
Phone:  617/353-3252
Fax:  617/353-5074

subject: [CRC] interesting talk on spatio-temporal models for brain imaging at MGH Brainmap tomorrow
bodyText:
Subject:
[Brainmap] Wednesday 2/16 at noon: Firdaus Janoos: Spatio-temporal  
Models for
Mental Processes from fMRI

Wednesday, February 16th, 2011 at 12pm
Seminar room 2204
149 13th St., Charlestown Navy Yard

Firdaus Janoos
Ohio State University

Spatio-temporal Models for Mental Processes from fMRI

Understanding the highly complex, spatially distributed and temporally
organized phenomena entailed by mental processes using functional MRI is
an important research problem in cognitive and clinical neuroscience.
Classically, the analysis of functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging  
(fMRI)
has focused either on the creation of static maps localizing the  
metabolic
fingerprints of neural processes or on studying their temporal evolution
in a few pre-selected regions in the human brain. However, cognition
recruits the entire brain and the underlying mental processes are
fundamentally spatio-temporal in nature. By neglecting either the  
temporal
dimension or the spatial entirety of brain function, such methods must
necessarily compromise on extracting and representing all the  
information
contained in the data. In this work, I present a new paradigm to
facilitate a multivariate spatio-temporal model that allows a
time-resolved exploration of mental processes as captured by fMRI.  
Using a
state-space formalism that models the brain transitioning through a
sequence of cognitive states as it solves a mental task, we are able to
study the spatial distribution of activity along with its temporal
structure. In addition to revealing the mental patterns of an individual
subject, such a generative model enables group-level inferences in terms
of information-theoretic properties such as complexity and mutual
information. Efficient algorithms for estimating the parameters,
state-sequence and the hemodynamic behavior of the brain have been
developed. This method was applied to a multi-subject fMRI study for
developmental disorders such as dyslexia and dyscalculia (i.e. math
learning disability). I shall show the kind of inferences possible with
this method in analyzing and differentiating the groups and the
neuro-scientific conclusions that it provides.
_______________________________________________
Brainmap website
http://www.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu/martinos/training/brainMap_2010-2011.php
[www.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu]

Brainmap subscription
https://mail.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/brainmap
[mail.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu]

bodyHtml:
Subject:
[Brainmap] Wednesday 2/16 at noon: Firdaus Janoos: Spatio-temporal Models for
Mental Processes from fMRI

Wednesday, February 16th, 2011 at 12pm
Seminar room 2204
149 13th St., Charlestown Navy Yard

Firdaus Janoos
Ohio State University

Spatio-temporal Models for Mental Processes from fMRI

Understanding the highly complex, spatially distributed and temporally
organized phenomena entailed by mental processes using functional MRI is
an important research problem in cognitive and clinical neuroscience.
Classically, the analysis of functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI)
has focused either on the creation of static maps localizing the metabolic
fingerprints of neural processes or on studying their temporal evolution
in a few pre-selected regions in the human brain. However, cognition
recruits the entire brain and the underlying mental processes are
fundamentally spatio-temporal in nature. By neglecting either the temporal
dimension or the spatial entirety of brain function, such methods must
necessarily compromise on extracting and representing all the information
contained in the data. In this work, I present a new paradigm to
facilitate a multivariate spatio-temporal model that allows a
time-resolved exploration of mental processes as captured by fMRI. Using a
state-space formalism that models the brain transitioning through a
sequence of cognitive states as it solves a mental task, we are able to
study the spatial distribution of activity along with its temporal
structure. In addition to revealing the mental patterns of an individual
subject, such a generative model enables group-level inferences in terms
of information-theoretic properties such as complexity and mutual
information. Efficient algorithms for estimating the parameters,
state-sequence and the hemodynamic behavior of the brain have been
developed. This method was applied to a multi-subject fMRI study for
developmental disorders such as dyslexia and dyscalculia (i.e. math
learning disability). I shall show the kind of inferences possible with
this method in analyzing and differentiating the groups and the
neuro-scientific conclusions that it provides.
_______________________________________________
Brainmap website
http://www.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu/martinos/training/brainMap_2010-2011.php
[www.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu]

Brainmap subscription
https://mail.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/brainmap
[mail.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu]

subject: Students and Postdoc - Coffee & Cookies with Andrew King + spARO
bodyText:
Hello all --

Firstly, there is an EPL SAP talk by Andrew King on Feb 25 Friday 2pm
(Friday after ARO) followed by coffee and cookie hour at EPL library for
students and post-docs. (Yes, we feed people only after the talk at EPL.) It
is a small meeting where you get to ask more detailed questions and also
learn about what other students and postdocs are up to. If you never been to
these post-SAP cookie hour, you should check it out!

Please let me know and stick around after the talk to join us! To learn more
about Dr King's research:
http://www.dpag.ox.ac.uk/academic_staff/andrew_king

Secondly, we are looking for new members to serve at the spARO steering
committee. Main duty is planning the student/postdoc event for the next ARO
and it is a great chance to meet your fellow junior members of ARO. Please
let me know if you would like to serve as a committee member.

Thank you!

-Yoojin

subject: [speechlabbu] Fwd: Wed 2/16, 2pm, Azadeh Yazdan-Shahmorad talk
bodyText:
---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: <jritt@bu.edu>
Date: Sat, Feb 12, 2011 at 3:21 PM
Subject: Wed 2/16, 2pm, Azadeh Yazdan-Shahmorad talk
To: "Colburn, H Steven" <colburn@bu.edu>, "Mountain, David C" <dcm@bu.edu>,
Barbara Shinn-Cunningham <shinn@cns.bu.edu>, Kamal Sen <kamalsen@bu.edu>,
Frank Guenther <fguenth@gmail.com>, Timothy J Gardner <timothyg@bu.edu>,
"Mertz, Jerome" <jmertz@bu.edu>


Hi all.  The following talk this Wed (hosted by my lab) may be of interest
to you or your labs.

Cheers,
Jason

---


Wed 2/16
2pm
LSE (24 Cummington)
2nd Floor Conference Room

Optimizing Cortical Electrical Stimulation Parameters for
Neurorehabilitation Applications

Azadeh Yazdan-Shahmorad

Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor

Cortical electrical stimulation (CES) has been used extensively in
experimental neuroscience to modulate neuronal or behavioral activity, which
has led this technique to be considered in neurorehabilitation. Because the
cortex and the surrounding anatomy have irregular geometries as well as
inhomogeneous and anisotropic electrical properties, the mechanisms by which
CES has therapeutic effects is poorly understood. Therapeutic effects of CES
can be improved by optimizing the stimulation parameters based on the
effects of various stimulation parameters on target brain regions.

In this study the effects of CES pulse polarity, frequency, and amplitude
were investigated on unit activity (spikes), local field potentials (LFP),
and electrocorticograms (ECoG) recorded from rat primary motor cortex. The
results showed that units located in lower cortical layers are
preferentially excited by anodic stimulation, while cathodic stimulation
excites those located in upper cortical layers. These opposing effects were
also frequency- and amplitude-dependent. Time-frequency analysis of LFPs
showed high correlation of gamma frequencies with unit activity in
corresponding layers. On the other hand, high gamma power of ECoG signals
only showed high correlation with the unit activity in lower layers.
Time-frequency correlations, which were found between LFPs, ECoGs and unit
activity were also frequency- and amplitude- dependent. The data
demonstrates that the poststimulus effects in neural activity after
manipulation of CES parameters changes according to the location (depth) of
the recorded neural activity in motor cortex. The signature of the neural
activity observed in LFP and ECoG signals provides a better understanding of
the effects of stimulation on the affected network and has a promising
potential to be used in closed-loop control stimulation systems. These
results demonstrate that the neurorehabilitation and neuroprosthetic
applications of CES can be further improved by optimizing CES parameters.






-- 
<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>
Frank Guenther
Professor, Departments of Speech, Language, & Hearing
   Sciences and Cognitive & Neural Systems
Associate Director, Graduate Program for Neuroscience
Boston University
677 Beacon Street
Boston, MA 02215
Phone: 617-353-5765   Fax: 617-353-7755
guenther@bu.edu <guenther@cns.bu.edu>
http://www.cns.bu.edu/~guenther

subject: Save the Date: 2nd Annual Translational Research Symposium, May 26, 2011
bodyText:
*BostonUniversity*
Clinical and Translational Science Institute

*_SAVE THE DATE_*

**

*Second Annual *

*Translational Research Symposium*

**

*Thursday, May 26, 2011*

**

*8:00 AM -- 3:00 PM*

**

*Boston University School of Management *

*595 Commonwealth Avenue, 4th Floor*

*Boston, MA 02115*

**

*Sponsored By:*

*The Boston University Clinical and Translational Science Institute (CTSI)*

*http://ctsi.bu.edu/*

*David Center, MD, Institute Director and Associate Provost for 
Translational Research ***

**

*_Activities will include_*

? Poster session, with prizes

? Short talks: translational research challenges and successes at Boston 
University

? Cross-campus networking and small group discussions

? Information on translational research resources at Boston University

**

*Keynote Speaker*

*Robert S. Langer, ScD*

*David H. Koch Institute Professor, Massachusetts Institute of Technology*

**

Robert S. Langer, ScD, is the David H. Koch Institute Professor at MIT. 
He is a professor of Chemical and Biomedical Engineering, a faculty 
member of the Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology, 
and a member of the David H. Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer 
Research. He is widely recognized for his contributions to the fields of 
drug delivery systems and tissue engineering, and is said to be the most 
cited engineer in history. His laboratory at MIT is the largest 
biomedical engineering lab in the world, with about $10 million in 
annual grants and 100 researchers. He has authored more than 1,100 
scientific papers and holds more than 760 granted or pending patents.

He has received numerous awards, including the National Medal of 
Science, the 10th Annual Heinz Award in the category of Technology, the 
Economy and Employment, the Charles Stark Draper Prize, the Lemelson-MIT 
Prize, the Albany Medical Center Prize in Medicine and Biomedical 
Research and the Millennium Technology Prize in 2008. Langer is the 
youngest person in history (at 43) to be elected to all three American 
science academies: the National Academy of Sciences, the National 
Academy of Engineering and the Institute of Medicine.

*//*

*/The full announcement, with the day's events and registration 
information will be sent in Mid-March./***

**

*Contact***

For questions regarding the Symposium, contact:

Courtney L Alpert alpertc@bu.edu <mailto:alpertc@bu.edu>

Tai Chen, PhD taichen@bu.edu <mailto:taichen@bu.edu>

David Seldin, MD, PhD dseldin@bu.edu <mailto:dseldin@bu.edu>

Description: Boston University <http://www.bu.edu/>

	

The CTSA <http://ctsi.bu.edu/> initiative is led by the National Center 
for Research Resources at the National Institute of Health.

ctsi.bu.edu <http://ctsi.bu.edu>

subject: Yi Zhou seminar Friday - reminder
bodyText:
Friday, Jan. 14, 2011
10:30AM-noon

TALK WILL PROBABLY BE IN ROOM 401... stay tuned..

Rm 203, 44 Cummington St.

Yi Zhou, PhD
Laboratory of Auditory Neurophysiology
Department of Biomedical Engineering, Johns Hopkins University
Title: Spatial and spectral processing in the primary auditory cortex
of awake primate

A realistic listening environment often consists of multiple sounds
from various spatial locations. Although the auditory cortex has been
shown to play important roles in sound localization, how cortical
neurons process mixed spatial and spectral information of multiple
sounds is not entirely clear. In this talk, I will discuss results on
spatial and frequency selectivity of individual neurons in the primary
auditory cortex (A1) of awake marmoset monkeys. I will show that the
spatial receptive fields (SRFs) of A1 neurons measured in the awake
condition typically contained a restricted excitatory region that was
surrounded by inhibition. Interestingly, the frequency selectivity of
A1 neurons was found to be largely location-invariant. These findings
indicate that A1 neurons receive widespread spatial inputs that are
composed of both excitation and inhibition and that the balance
between excitatory and inhibitory inputs results in spatial
selectivity of A1 neurons without altering their frequency
selectivity. This joint spatial and spectral processing scheme may
underlie A1 neurons? ability to encode spatial-spectral-temporal
relationships of multiple sounds.

subject: "BINAURAL TALK" NEXT TUESDAY  AT 2 PM- Richard Stern
bodyText:
Rich Stern from Carnegie Mellon U. will be here all day next Tuesday. 
He is giving a talk from 2 to 3 pm on a topic of great interest to me 
and to many people these days.
(The talk will be in Room 203 of 44 Cummington Street.)

TITLE:   "The impact of the distribution of internal delays in binaural 
models on predictions for psychoacoustical data" 
       OR  "Revisionist theories in binaural hearing .... does the 
distribution of delays really matter?"

ABSTRACT:
Jeffress's theory of binaural interaction has played a dominant role in 
the modeling of binaural phenomena since its introduction more than 60 
years ago. Central to these models is a network of binaural 
coincidence-counting units that respond to simultaneous excitation from 
each of the two ears after a fixed internal delay. The predictions of 
these models for a broad range of binaural phenomena, including 
subjective lateral position, interaural discrimination, binaural 
detection, and dichotic pitch, are critically dependent on the shape of 
the function that describes the distribution of the binaural units with 
respect to their internal delays and best frequencies. In recent years 
new theories have challenged the traditional notion that the 
distribution function that best describes the widest variety of 
perceptual data is a broadly tapered function that decreases 
monotonically with increasing internal delay. Most arguments in support 
of the new theories have been based on physiological evidence or on the 
results of a limited set of psychoacoustical experiments. In this talk 
we will review the considerations that have motivated the traditional 
assumptions about the distributions of the internal delays, and we will 
critically evaluate the extent to which the new theories as well as the 
traditional binaural models are able to describe and predict 
experimental results for the broadest set of binaural perceptual 
phenomena, independently of physiological considerations.

ABOUT RICH STERN:

Richard M. Stern received the S.B. degree from the Massachusetts 
Institute of Technology in 1970, the M.S. from the University of 
California, Berkeley, in 1972, and the Ph.D. from MIT in 1977, all in 
electrical engineering. He has been on the faculty of Carnegie Mellon 
University since 1977, where he is currently a Professor in the 
Electrical and Computer Engineering, Computer Science, and Biomedical 
Engineering Departments, the Language Technologies Institute, and a 
Lecturer in the School of Music. Dr. Stern's initial research had been 
in the area of auditory perception, where he is best known for 
theoretical work in binaural perception. Much of Dr. Stern's current 
research is in spoken language systems, where he is particularly 
concerned with the development of both physiologically-motivated and 
statistically-based techniques with which automatic speech recognition 
can be made more robust with respect to changes in environment and 
acoustical ambience. Dr. Stern is a Fellow of the Acoustical Society of 
America, the 2008-2009 Distinguished Lecturer of the International 
Speech Communication Association, a recipient of the Allen Newell Award 
for Research Excellence in 1992, and he served as General Chair of 
Interspeech 2006. He is also a member of the IEEE and the Audio 
Engineering Society.
bodyHtml:
Rich Stern from Carnegie Mellon U. will be here all day next Tuesday. 
He is giving a talk from 2 to 3 pm on a topic of great interest to me and to many people these days.
(The talk will be in Room 203 of 44 Cummington Street.)

TITLE:   "The impact of the distribution of internal delays in binaural models on predictions for psychoacoustical data" 
       OR  "Revisionist theories in binaural hearing …. does the distribution of delays really matter?"

ABSTRACT:
Jeffress's theory of binaural interaction has played a dominant role in the modeling of binaural phenomena since its introduction more than 60 years ago. Central to these models is a network of binaural coincidence-counting units that respond to simultaneous excitation from each of the two ears after a fixed internal delay. The predictions of these models for a broad range of binaural phenomena, including subjective lateral position, interaural discrimination, binaural detection, and dichotic pitch, are critically dependent on the shape of the function that describes the distribution of the binaural units with respect to their internal delays and best frequencies. In recent years new theories have challenged the traditional notion that the distribution function that best describes the widest variety of perceptual data is a broadly tapered function that decreases monotonically with increasing internal delay. Most arguments in support of the new theories have been based on physiological evidence or on the results of a limited set of psychoacoustical experiments. In this talk we will review the considerations that have motivated the traditional assumptions about the distributions of the internal delays, and we will critically evaluate the extent to which the new theories as well as the traditional binaural models are able to describe and predict experimental results for the broadest set of binaural perceptual phenomena, independently of physiological considerations.

ABOUT RICH STERN:

Richard M. Stern received the S.B. degree from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1970, the M.S. from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1972, and the Ph.D. from MIT in 1977, all in electrical engineering. He has been on the faculty of Carnegie Mellon University since 1977, where he is currently a Professor in the Electrical and Computer Engineering, Computer Science, and Biomedical Engineering Departments, the Language Technologies Institute, and a Lecturer in the School of Music. Dr. Stern’s initial research had been in the area of auditory perception, where he is best known for theoretical work in binaural perception. Much of Dr. Stern's current research is in spoken language systems, where he is particularly concerned with the development of both physiologically-motivated and statistically-based techniques with which automatic speech recognition can be made more robust with respect to changes in environment and acoustical ambience. Dr. Stern is a Fellow of the Acoustical Society of America, the 2008-2009 Distinguished Lecturer of the International Speech Communication Association, a recipient of the Allen Newell Award for Research Excellence in 1992, and he served as General Chair of Interspeech 2006. He is also a member of the IEEE and the Audio Engineering Society.
